note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Ʋirolet.
sp.l: _BOy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: If my wife ſeek me, tell her that
Deſignes of weight, too heavy for her knowledge,
Exact my privacy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I ſhall, ſir.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: Do then,
And leave me to my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Tis a raw morning,
And would you pleaſe to interpret that for duty
Which you may conſtrue boldneſſe, I could wiſh
To arme your ſelfe againſt it, you would uſe
More of my ſervice.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: I have heate within here,
A noble heat (good boy) to keep it off,
I ſhall not freeze; deliver my excuſe, Enter Julian●.
And you have done your part.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: That is prevented,
My Lady follows you.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Since I muſt be croſt then,
Let her perform that office.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I obey you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: Prethee to bed; to be thus fond's more tedious
Then if I were neglected.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tis the fault then
Of love and duty which I would fall under,
Rather then want that care which you may challenge
As due to my obedience.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I confeſſe
This tenderneſſe argues a loving wife,
And more deſerves my hearts beſt thanks then anger.
Yet I muſt tell ye Sweet, you do exceed
In your affection, if you would ingroſſe me
To your delights alone.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am not jealous,
If my embraces have diſtaſted you,
As I muſt grant you every way ſo worthy
That tis not in weak woman to deſerve you,
Much leſſe in miſerable me, that want
Thoſe graces ſome more fortunate are ſtor'd with.
Seek any whom you pleaſe, and I will ſtudy
With my beſt ſervice to deſerve thoſe favours,
That ſhall yeeld you contentment.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You are miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No, I am patient ſir, and ſo good morrow;
I will not be offenſive.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Heare my reaſons.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Though in your life a widdows bed receives me,
For your ſake I muſt love it. May ſhe proſper
That ſhall ſucceed me in it, and your ardour
Laſt longer to her.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: By the love I beare
Firſt to my Countries peace, next to thy ſelfe
To whom compar'd, my life I rate at nothing;
Stood here a Lady that were the choyce abſtract
Of all the beauties nature ever faſhion'd,
Or Art gave ornament to, compar'd to thee,
Thus as thou art obedient and loving,
I ſhould contemne and loath her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I do believe ye.
How I am bleſt
In my aſſur'd beliefe? this is unfain'd;
And why this ſadneſſe then?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Why Juliana,
Believe me, theſe my ſad and dull retirements,
My often, nay almoſt continued faſts,
Sleep baniſht from my eyes, all pleaſures ſtrangers,
Have neither root nor growth from any cauſe
That may arrive at woman. Shouldſt thou be,
As chaſtity forbid, falſe to my bed,
I ſhould lament my fortune, perhaps puniſh
Thy falſhood, and then ſtudy to forget thee:
But that which like a never emptied ſpring,
Feeds high the torrent of my ſwelling griefe,
Is what my Countrey ſuffers; there's a ground
Where ſorrow may be planted, and ſpring up,
Though yeelding rage and womaniſh deſpaire,
And yet not ſhame the owner.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I do believe it true,
Yet I ſhould think my ſelfe a happy woman,
If in this generall and timely mourning,
I might or give to you, or elſe receive
A little lawfull comfort.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Thy diſcretion
In this may anſwer for me; look on Naples
The Countrey where we both were born and bred,
Naples the Paradiſe of Italy,
As that is of the earth; Naples, that was
The ſweet retreat of all the worthieſt Romans,
When they had ſhar'd the ſpoyles of the whole world;
This flouriſhing Kingdom, whoſe inhabitants
For wealth and bravery liv'd like petty Kings,
Made ſubject now to ſuch a tyranny,
As that faire City that receiv'd her name
From Conſtantine the great, now in the power
Of barbarous Infidels, may forget her own,
To look with pity on our miſeries,
So far in our calamities we tranſcend her.
For ſince this Arragonian tyrant Ferrand,
Ceaz'd on the government, there's nothing left us
That we can call our own, but our afflictions,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And hardly thoſe; the Kings ſtrange cruelty,
Equals all preſidents of Tyranny.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Equall ſay you:
He has out gone, the worſt compar'd to him;
Nor Phalaris, nor Dioniſius,
Caligula, nor Nero can be mention'd;
They yet as Kings, abus'd their regall power;
This as a Marchant, all the Countries fatt,
He wholy does ingroſſe unto himſelf;
Our Oyles he buyes at his own price, then ſels them
To us, at dearer rates; our Plate and Jewels,
Under a fayn'd pretence of publique uſe,
He borrows; which deny'd, his Inſtruments force.
The raſes of our horſes, he takes from us;
Yet keeps them in our paſtures; rapes of Matrons,
And Virgins, are too frequent; never man
Yet thank'd him for a pardon; for Religion,
It is a thing he dreames not off.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I have heard,
How true it is, I know not; that he ſold
The Biſhop-prick of Tarent to a Jew,
For thirteene thouſand Duckets.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I was preſent,
And ſaw the money paid▪ the day would leave me,
Ere I could number out his impious actions;
Or what the miſerable Subject ſuffers;
And can you entertaine in ſuch a time,
A thought of dalliance? teares, and ſighes, and groanes,
Would better now become you.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: They indeed are,
The onely weapons, our poor Sex can uſe,
When we are injur'd, and they may become us;
But for men that were born free men, of Ranck;
That would be regiſtred Fathers of their Country;
And to have on their Tombs in Golden Letters,
The noble ſtile of Tyrant killers, written;
To weepe like fooles, and women and not like wiſe men.
To practiſe a redreſſe, deſerves a name,
Which fits not me to give.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Thy grave reproofe:
If what thou doſt deſire, were poſſible
To be effected? might well argue it,
As wiſe as loving; but if you conſider,
With what ſtrong guards, this Tyrant is defended:
Ruffins, and malecontents drawne from all quarters;
That onely know, to ſerve his impious will;
The Citadels built by him in the neck
Of this poor City; the invinceſible ſtrength,
Nature by Art aſſiſted, gave this Caſtle;
And above all his feare; admitting no man
To ſee him, but unarm'd; it being death
For any to approach him with a weapon.
You muſt confeſſe, unleſſe our hands were Canons,
To batter down theſe walls; our weake breath mines,
To blow his Forts up; or our curſes lightning,
To force a paſſage to him; and then blaſt him;
Our power is like to yours, and we like you;
Weepe our misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Walls of Braſſe reſiſt not
A noble undertaking: nor can vice,
Raiſe any Bulwrack, to make good the place,
Where vertue ſeekes to enter; then to fall
In ſuch a brave attempt, were ſuch an honour;
That Brutus, did he live again would envy.
Were my dead Father in you, and my Brothers;
Nay, all the Anceſtors I am deriv'd from;
As you, in being what you are, are all theſe.
I had rather weare a mourning Garment for you,
And ſhould be more proud of my widdow-hood;
You dying for the freedome of this Country;
Then if I were aſſur'd, I ſhould injoy
A perpetuity of life and pleaſure,
With you the Tyrant living.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Till this minute,
I never heard thee ſpeake; O more then woman!
And more to be belov'd; can I finde out
A Cabinet, to lock a ſecret in,
Of equall truſt to thee? all doubts, and feares,
That ſcandalize your ſex, be farre from me;
Thou ſhalt pertake my neer and deareſt councels,
And further them with thine.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I will be faithfull.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Know then this day, ſtand heaven propitious to us,
Our liberty begins.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: In Ferrands death?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: 'Tis plotted love, and ſtrongly, and beleeve it,
For nothing elſe could doe it; 'twas the thought,
How to proceed in this deſigne and end it,
That made ſtrange my embraces.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Curs'd be ſhe,
That's ſo indulgent to her own delights,
That for their ſatisfaction, would give
A ſtop to ſuch a glorious enterprize:
For me, I would not for the world, I had been
Guilty of ſuch a crime; goe on and proſper.
Goe on my deareſt Lord, I love your Honour
Above my life; nay, yours; my Prayers go with you;
Which I will ſtrengthen with my teares: the wrongs
Of this poor Country, edge your ſword; O may it
Peirce deep into this Tyrants heart, and then
When you return bath'd in his guilty bloud,
I'le waſh you cleane with fountaines of true joy.
But who are your aſſiſtants? though I am
So covetous of your glory, that I could wiſh
You had no ſharer in it. Knock.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Be not curious.
They come, how ever you command my boſome,
To them I would not have you ſeene.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I am gon Sir,
Be confident; and may my reſolution
Be preſent with you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Such a Maſculine ſpirit,
With more then womans vertues, were a dower
To waigh down a Kings fortune.

sp.speaker: Briſſ.
sp.p: Good day to you. Enter Briſſonet Camillo, Ronvere.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: You are an early ſtirrer.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: What new face,
Bring you along?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: If I ſtand doubted Sir?
As by your looks I gueſſe it: you much injure
A man that loves, and truly loves this Country,
With as much zeale as you doe; one that hates
The Prince by whom it ſuffers, and as deadly;
One that dares ſtep as farre to gaine my freedome,
As any he that breathes; that weares a ſword
As ſharp as any's.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Nay, no more compariſons.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: What you but whiſper, I dare ſpeake aloud,
Stood the King by; have meanes to put in act too
What you but coldly plot; if this deſerve then
Suſpition in the beſt, the boldeſt, wiſeſt?
Purſue your own intents, il'e follow mine;
And if I not out-ſtrip you—

sp.speaker: Briſſ.
sp.l: Be aſſur'd Sir,
A conſcience like this can never be allide
To treachery.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Who durſt ſpeake ſo much,
But one that is like us a ſufferer,
And ſtands as we affected?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You are cozend
And all undone; every Intelligencer
Speakes treaſon with like licence; is not this
Ronvere, that hath for many yeeres been train'd
In Ferrands Schoole, a man in truſt and favour,
Rewarded too and highly?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Grant all this,
The thought of what he was, being as he is now;
A man diſgrac'd, and with contempt thrown o●f;
Will ſpurre him to revenge, as ſwift as they,
That never were in favour.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Poore and childiſh.

sp.speaker: Briſſ.
sp.l: His regiment is caſt, that is moſt certain;
And his command in the Caſtle given away.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: That on my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Groſſer ſtill, what ſhepheard
Would yeeld the poor remainder of his flock,
To a known wolfe; though he put on the habit,
Of a moſt faithfull dogge, and barke like one?
As this but onely talkes.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yes, he has meanes too.

sp.speaker: Virol.
sp.l: I know it to my griefe, weake men I know it;
To make his peace, if there were any warre
Between him and his Maſter, betraying
Our innocent lives.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: You are too ſuſpitious;
And I have born too much, beyon'd my temper,
Take your own wayes, i'le leave you.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You may ſtay now;
You have enough, and all indeed you fiſht for;
But one word Gentlemen: have you diſcover'd
To him alone our plot?

sp.speaker: Briſſ.
sp.l: To him and others, that are at his devotion.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Worſe and worſe:
For were he onely conſcious of our purpoſe,
Though with the breach of Hoſpitable lawes,
In my own houſe, ide ſilence him for ever:
But what is paſt my help, is paſt my care,
I have a life to looſe.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Have better hopes.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: And when you know, with what charge I have further'd
Your noble undertaking, you will ſweare me
Another man; the guards I have corrupted:
And of the choyce of all our nobleſt youths,
Attir'd like virgins; ſuch as Hermits would
Welcome to their ſad cells, prepar'd a Maske;
As done for the Kings pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: For his ſafety
I rather feare; and as a pageant to
Uſher our ruine.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: We as Torch-bearers
Will waite on theſe, but with ſuch art and cunning;
I have convei'd ſharp poniards in the Wax,
That we may paſſe, though ſearch't through all his guards
Without ſuſpition, and in all his glory,
Oppreſſe him, and with ſafety.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: 'Tis moſt ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: To be effected.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: You are doubtfull ſtill.

sp.speaker: Briſſ.
sp.l: But we reſolv'd to follow him, and if you
Deſiſt now Virolet, we will ſay 'tis feare,
Rather then providence. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And ſo we leave you, Enter Julian.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: To your wiſe doubts, and to my better councels;
Oh! pardon me my Lord, and truſt me too;
Let me not like Caſſandra propheſie truths,
And never be beleiv'd, before the miſchiefe:
I have heard all; know this Ronvere a villaine,
A villaine that hath tempted me, and plotted
This for your ruine, onely to make way
To his hopes in my embraces; at more leiſure
I will acquaint you, wherefore I conceil'd it
To this laſt minute; if you ſtay you are loſt,
And all prevention too late. I know,
And 'tis to me known onely, a darke cave
Within this houſe, a part of my poor dower,
Where you may lye conceal'd, as in the center,
Till this rough blaſt be ore; where there is ayre,
More then to keep in life; Ferrand will find you,
So curious his feares are.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: 'Tis better fall
Then hide my head, now 'twas thine own advice,
My friends ingag'd too.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: You ſtand further bound,
Then to weake men that have betray'd themſelves,
Or to my Councell, though then juſt and loyall:
Your phanſie hath been good, but not your judgement,
In choyce of ſuch to ſide you, wil you leape
From a ſteep Tower, becauſe a deſperate foole
Does it, and truſts the wind to ſave his hazard?
There's more expected from you; all mens eyes are fixt
On Viriolet, to help not hurt them;
Make good their hopes and ours, you have ſworn often,
That you dare credit me; and allow'd me wiſe
Although a woman; even Kings in great Actions,
Waite opportunity and ſo muſt you Sir,
Or looſe your underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Thou art conſtant;
I am uncertain foole, a moſt blinde foole;
Be thou my guide.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I. I faile to direct you,
For torment or reward, when I am wretched,
May conſtancy forſake me.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I've my ſatety.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Why are you rapt thus?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Peace, thou art a foole.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: But if I were a flatterer like your worſhip,
I ſhould be wiſe and rich too;
There are few elſe that proſper, baudes excepted,
They hold an equall place there.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: A ſhrew'd knave;
But O the King, the happy King!

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Why happy?
In bearing a great burthen.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: What beares he,
That's born on Princes ſhoulders?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: A Crownes waight,
Which ſets more heavy on his head, then the ore
Slaves digge out of the Mines, of which 'tis made.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Thou worthily art his fool, to think that heavy
That carryes him in the ayre; the reverence due
To that moſt ſacred Gold, makes him ador'd,
His Foot-ſteps kiſt, his ſmiles to raiſe a begger
To a Lords fortune; and when he but frownes,
The City quakes.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Or the poor Cuckolds in it,
Cox-combs I ſhould ſay, I am of a foole.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Grown a Philoſopher, to heare this paraſite.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: The delicates he is ſerv'd with ſee and envy,

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I had rather have an Onyon with a ſtomack,
Then theſe without one.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: The Celeſtiall Muſick, ſtill Muſick.
Such as the motion of the eternall ſpheares
Yeelds Iove, when he drinkes Nectar.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Here's a fine knave, yet hath to many fellowes.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Then the beauties,
That with variety of choyce embraces, theſe paſſe o're.
Renew his age.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Help him to croutch rather,
And the French Cringe, they are excellent Surgeons that way.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: O Majeſty! let others think of heaven,
While I contemplate thee.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: This is not Atheiſme, but Court obſervance.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Now the God appears, uſher'd with earth-quakes.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Baſe Idolatry. Flouriſh Enter Ferrand, Guard, women, Servants.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Theſe meates are poyſoned, hang
The Cookes; no note more, on
Forfeit of your fingers; doe you
Envy me a minutes ſlumber, what are theſe?

sp.speaker: 1. Gu.
sp.l: The Ladies appointed by your Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To the purpoſe, for what appointed?

sp.speaker: 1. Gu.
sp.l: For your graces pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To ſucke away the little bloud is left me,
By my continuall cares; I am not apt now,
Injoy them firſt, ta●●e of my dyet once;
And your turne ſerv'd, for fifty Crownes a peece
Their Husbands may redeem them.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.l: Great Sir, mercy.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I am deafe, why ſtare you? is what we command
To be diſputed? who's this? bring you the dead
T'upbrai'd me to my face?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Hold Emperour;
Hold mighteſt of Kings, I am thy vaſſell,
Thy Foot-ſtool, that durſt not preſume to look
On thy offended face.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Caſtruchio riſe.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Let not the lightning of thy eye conſume me,
Nor heare that Muſicall tongue, in dreadfull thunder,
That ſpeak●s all mercy.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Here's no ſlattering rogue.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Ferrand, that is the Father of his people,
The glory of mankinde.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No more, no word more;
And while I tell my troubles to my ſelfe,
Be Statues without motion or voyce,
Though to be flatter'd, is an itch to greatneſſe,
It now offends me.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Here's the happy man;
But ſpeake who dares.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: When I was innocent;
I yet remember, I could eat and ſleepe,
Walke unaffrighted, but now terrible to others:
My guards cannot keepe feare from me
It ſtill purſues me; Oh! my wounded conſcience,
The Bed I would reſt in, is ſtuft with thornes;
The grounds ſtrow'd o're with adders, and with aſpicks
Where ere I ſet my foot, but I am in,
And what was got with cruelty, with blood,
Muſt be defended, though this lifes a hell,
I feare a worſe hereafter▪ ha!

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: My Lord. Enter Ronvere and guard.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Welcome Ronvere, welcome my golden plummet
With which I ſound mine enemies depthes and angers,
Haſt thou diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: All as you could wiſh Sir,
The Plot, and the contrivers; was made one
Of the conſpiracie.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Is Virolet in?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: The head of all, he onely ſcented me:
And from his feare, that I plaid falſe is fled;
The reſt I have in fetters

sp.speaker: Fer
sp.l: Death and hell.
Next to my mortall foe the pyrat Seſſe,
I aym'd at him; he's vertuous, and wiſe,
A lover of his freedome and his countries
Dangerous to ſuch as govern by the ſword,
And ſo to me: no tract which way he went,
No meanes to overtake him?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Ther's ſome hope left;
But with a rough hand, to be ſeaſ'd upon.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: If any know, or where he is,
Or which way he is fled, it is his wife;
Her with his Father I have apprehended,
And brought among the reſt.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Twas wiſely order'd,
Go fetch them in, and let my executioners Exit Ronvere.
Appeare in horrour with the racke.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: I take it ſigneur, this is no time for you to flatter,
Or me to foole in.

sp.speaker: Caſt
sp.l: Thou art wiſe in this, let's off, it is unſafe to be nere Jove,
When he begins to thunder.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Good morality. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I that have peirc'd into the hearts of men;
Forc'd them to lay open with my lookes,
Secrets whoſe leaſ● diſcovery was death,
Will rend for what concernes my life, the fortreſſe,
Of a weake womans faith. Enter Ronvere, guard, Executioners with a Rack, Camillo, Briſſonet Pandulfo, Juliana.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: What ere we ſuffer,
The waight, that loads a Traytors
Heart ſit ever, heavy on thine.

sp.speaker: Briſſ
sp.l: As we are caught by thee,
Fall thou by others.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Piſh poor fools, your curſes will
Never reach me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Now by my Ʋirolets life;
Father, this is a glori●us ſtage of murther.
Here are five properties too, and ſuch ſpectators,
As will expect good action, to the life;
Let us performe our parts, and we ſhall live,
When theſe are rotten, would we might begin once;
Are you the Maſter of the company?
Troth you are tedious now.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: She does deride me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Thee and thy Power, if one poor ſyllable
Could win me, an aſſurance of thy favour,
I would not ſpeake it, I deſire to be
The great example of thy cruelty,
To whet which one, know Ferrand, I alone
Can make diſcovery, where my Virolet is,
Whoſe life, I know thou aym'ſt at, but if tortures
Compell me to't, may hope of heaven for ſake me;
I dare thy worſt.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Are we contemn'd.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Thou art,
Thou and thy Miniſters, my life is thine;
But in the death, the Victory ſhall be mine.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: We have ſuch a Miſtreſſe here to teach us courage,
That cowards might learn from her.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You are ſlow; put on the rack.
Begin the Scene thou miſerable foole
For ſo I'le make thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis not in thy reach;
I am happy in my ſufferings, thou moſt wretched.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: So brave! Ile tame you yet, pluck hard villains;
Is ſhe inſenſible? no ſigh nor groan? or is ſhe dead?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No tyrant, though I ſuffer
More then a woman, beyond fleſh and blood;
Tis in a cauſe ſo honourable, that I ſcorn
With any ſign that may expreſſe a ſorrow
To ſhew I do repent.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Confeſſe yet,
And thou ſhal be ſafe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tis wrapt up in my ſoule,
From whence thou canſt not force it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I will be
Ten daies a killing thee.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Be twenty thouſand,
My glory lives the longer.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Tis a miracle,
She tires th'executioners,
And me.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Unlooſe her, I am conquer'd, I muſt take
Some other way; reach her my chaire, in honour
Of her invincible fortitude.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Will you not
Diſpatch the reſt?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: When I ſeem mercifull,
Aſſure thy ſelfe Ronvere, I am moſt cruell.
Thou wonder of thy ſex, and of this Nation,
That haſt chang'd my ſeverity to mercy,
Not to thy ſelfe alone, but to thy people,
In which I do include theſe men, my enemies:
Unbind them.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: This is ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: For your intent
Againſt my life, which you dare not deny,
I onely aske one ſervice.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Above hope.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: There rides a Pyrate neer, the Duke of Seſſe,
My enemy and this Countries, that in bonds
Holds my deere friend Aſcanio: free this friend,
Or bring the Pyrats head; beſides your pardon,
And honour of the action, your reward
Is forty thouſand Ducates. And becauſe
I know that Virolet is as bold as wiſe,
Be he your Generall, as pledge of your faith,
That you wil undertake it: let this old man,
And this moſt conſtant Matron ſtay with me;
Of whom, as of my ſelfe, I wil be carefull;
She ſhall direct you where her husband is.
Make choice of any ſhip you think moſt uſeful.
They are rig'd for you.

div.stage: Exeunt Guard, with Juliana and Pand.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: We with joy accept it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And wil proclaim King Ferrant mercifull.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: The myſterie of this, my Lord? or are you
Chang'd in your nature?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ile make thee private to it.
The lives of theſe weake men, and deſperate woman,
Would no way have ſecur'd me, had I took them;
Tis Virolet I aime at; he has power,
And knows to hurt. If they encounter Seſſe,
And he prove conquerour, I am aſſur'd
They'l finde no mercy: if that they prove victors,
I ſhall recover with my friend; his head
I moſt deſire of all men.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Now I have it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ile make thee underſtand the drift of all.
So we ſtand ſure, thus much for thoſe that fall. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: Ley here before the wind; up with her Canvaſe
And let her work, the wind begins to whiſ●le;
Clap all her ſtreamers on, and let her dance,
As if ſhe were the Minion of the Ocean.
Let her beſtride the billows till they rore,
And curle their wanton heads. Ho, below there:
Ho, ho, within.
Ley her North-eaſt, and thruſt her miſſen out,
The day grows faire and cleare, and the wind Courts us.
O for a luſty ſaile now, to give chaſe to.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: A ſtubborn Barke, that wo'd but bear up to us,
And change a broadſide bravely.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: Where's the Duke?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: I have not ſeen him ſtir to day.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: O Gunner,
What bravery dwels in his age, and what valour?
And to his friends, what gentleneſſe and bounty?
How long have we been inhabitants at Sea here?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Some fourteen yeers.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: By fourteen lives I ſwear then,
This Element never nouriſht ſuch a Pirate;
So great, ſo fearleſſe, and ſo fortunate,
So patient in his want, in Act ſo valiant.
How many ſaile of wel man'd ſhips before us,
As the Bonuto does the flying fiſh,
Have we purſued and ſcowerd, that to outſtrip us,
They have been fain to hang their very ſhirts on?
What Gallies have we bang'd, and ſunke, and taken;
Whoſe onely fraughts were fire, and ſtern defiance?
And nothing ſpoke but Bullet in all theſe.
How like old Neptune have I ſeen our Generall
Standing ith' Poope, and toſſing his ſteel Trident,
Commanding both the Sea and Winds to ſerve him?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: His daughter too, which is the honour, Boteſwain,
Of all her ſex; that Martiall mayd.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: A brave wench.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: How oftentimes, a fight being new begun,
Has ſhe leap'd down, and took my Linſtock from me,
And crying, now fly right, fir'd all my chaſers?
Then like the Image of the warlike Goddeſſe,
Her Target brac'd upon her arme, her Sword drawn,
And anger in her eyes, leap'd up again,
And bravely hal'd the Barke. I have wondred Botſwain,
That in a body made ſo delicate,
So ſoft for ſweet embraces, ſo much fire,
And manly ſoule, not ſtarting at a danger.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: Her Noble father got her in his fury,
And ſo ſhe proves a ſouldier.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: This to I wonder at,
Taking ſo many ſtrangers as he does,
He uſes them with that reſpect and coolneſſe,
Not making prize, but onely borrowing
What may ſupply his want: nor that for nothing;
But renders back what they may ſtand in need of,
And then parts lovingly: Where, if he take
His Countreyman, that ſhould be neereſt to him,
And ſtand moſt free from danger, he ſure pays for't:
He drownes or hangs the men, ranſacks the Barke,
Then gives her up a Bonfire to his fortune.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: The wrongs he has receiv'd from that dull Countrey,
That's all I know has purchas'd all his cruelty.
We fare the better; cheerly, cheerly boys,
The ſhip runs merrily; my Captain's melancholy,
And nothing cures that in him but a Sea-fight:
I hope to meet a ſaile boy, and a right one.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: That's my hope too; I am ready for the paſtime.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: I'th mean time let's beſtow a ſong upon him,
To ſhake him from his dumps, and bid good day to him.
Ho, in the hold. Enter a Boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Here, here.

sp.speaker: Boteſ.
sp.l: To th' main top boy.
And thou kenſt a ſhip that dares defie us,
Here's Gold.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I am gon. Exit Boy.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: Come ſirs, a queint Levet. Trump. a levet.
To waken our brave Generall. Then to our labour.

div.stage: Enter Duke of Seſse above and his daughter Martia like an Amazon.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: I thank you loving mates; I thank you all.
There's to prolong your mirth, & good morrow to you.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Take this from me, you'r honeſt valiant friends;
And ſuch we muſt make much of. Not a ſayle ſtirring?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Not any within ken yet.

sp.speaker: Boteſ.
sp.l: Without doubt Lady,
The wind ſtanding ſo faire and full upon us,
We ſhal have ſport anon. But noble Generall,
Why are you ſtill ſo ſad? you take our edge off;
You make us dull, and ſpirit-leſſe.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Ile tell ye,
Becauſe I wil provoke you to be fortunate;
For when you know my cauſe, twill double arme you.
This woman never knew it yet; my daughter,
Some diſcontents ſhe has.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Pray ſir go forward.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Theſe fourteen yeeres, I have ſtoed it here at Sea,
Where the moſt curious thought could never find it.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: Call up the Maſter, and all the Mates.

div.stage: Enter below the Maſter and Saylers.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Good morrow.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Good morrow to our Generall, good one,
And to that Noble Lady all good wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: I thank you Maſter.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Mark me, thus it is then;
Which I did never think to have diſcovered,
Till full revenge had wooed me; but to ſatisfie
My faithfull friends, thus I caſt off my burden.
In that ſhort time I was a Courtier,
And followed that moſt hated of all Princes,
Ferrant the full example of all miſchiefes,
Compel'd to follow to my ſoule a ſtranger,
It was my chance one day to play at Cheſſe
For ſome few Crowns, with a mynion of this Kings,
A mean poor man, that onely ſerv'd his pleaſures;
Removing of a Rook, we grew to words;
From this to hotter anger: to be ſhort,
I got a blow.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: How, how my Noble father?

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: A blow my girle, which I had ſoon repayd,
And ſunk the ſlave for ever, had not odds
Thruſt in betwixt us. I went away diſgrac'd—

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: For honours ſake not ſo ſir.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: For that time, wench;
But calld upon him, like a Gentleman,
By many private friends; knockt at his valour,
Courted his honour hourely to repaire me;
And tho he were a thing my thoughts made ſleight on,
And onely worth the fury of my footman,
Still I purſued him Nobly.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Did he eſcape you?
My old brave father, could you ſit down ſo coldly?

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Have patience, and know all. Purſued him fairly,
Till I was laught at, ſcornd, my wrongs made maygames.
By him unjuſtly wrong'd, ſhould be all juſtice,
The ſlave protected; yet at length I found him,
Found him, when he ſuppos'd all had been buried;
And what I had received durſt not be queſtioned;
And then he fell, under my Sword he fell,
For ever ſunk; his poore life, like the ayre,
Blown in an empty bubble, burſt, and left him,
No Noble wind of memory to raiſe him.
But then began my miſery, I fled;
The Kings frowns following, and my friends diſpaires;
No hand that durſt relieve: my Countrey fearfull,
Baſely and weakly fearfull of a tyrant;
Which made his bad wil worſe, ſtood ſtill and wondred,
Their vertues bedrid in e'm; then my girle,
A little one, I ſnatch'd thee from thy nurſe,
The modell of thy fathers miſeries:
And ſome ſmall wealth was fit for preſent carriage,
And got to Seal; where I profeſt my anger,
And wil do, whilſt that baſe ungratefull Countrey,
And that bad King, have blood or means to quench me.
Now ye know all.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: We know all, and admire all;
Go on and do all ſtill, and ſtill be fortunate.

sp.speaker: Daught.
sp.l: Had you done leſſe, or loſt this Noble anger,
You had been worthy then mens empty pities,
And not their wonders. Go on, and uſe your juſtice;
And uſe it ſtill with that fell violence
It firſt appeared to you; if you go leſſe,
Or take a doting mercy to protection,
The honour of a father I diſclaim in you,
Call back all duty, and will be prowder of
The infamous and baſe name of a whore,
Then daughter to a great Duke and a coward.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Mine own ſweet Martia, no; thou knowſt my nature,
It cannot, muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: I hope it ſhal not.
But why ſir, do you keep alive ſtill young Aſcanio,
Prince of Roſſana, King Ferrants moſt belov'd one,
You took two moneths agoe?
Why is not he flung overboord, or hang'd?

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Ile tell thee girle:
It were a mercy in my nature now,
So ſoon to break the bed of his afflictions;
I am not ſo far reconcil'd yet to him
To let him die, that were a benefit.
Beſides, I keep him as a bayt and dyet,
To draw on more, and neerer to the King,
I look each hour to heare of his Armados,
And a hot welcome they ſhall have.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: But hark you?
If you were overſwayed with oddes —

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: I find you:
I would not yield; no girle, no hope of yeelding,
Nor fling my ſelf one houre into their mercies,
And give the tyrant hope to gain his Kingdom.
No, I can ſink wench, and make ſhift to die;
A thouſand doores are open, I ſhal hit one.
I am no niggard of my life, ſo it goe Nobly:
All waies are equall and all houres; I care not.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Now you ſpeak like my father.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Noble General,
If by our means they inherit ought but bangs,
The mercy of the main yard light upon us.
No, we can ſinke too ſir, and ſinke low enough,
To poſe their cruelties, to follow us:
And he that thinks of life, if the world go that way,
A thouſand cowards ſuck his bones.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Let the worſt come,
I can unbreech a Canon, and without much help
Turn her into the Keele; and when ſhe has ſplit it,
Every man knows his way, his own prayers,
And ſo good night I think.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: We have liv'd all with you, Boy a top.
And will die with you Generall.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: I thank you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Boy above.
sp.l: A Sayle, a Sayle.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: A cheerfull ſound.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A Sayle.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: Of whence? of whence boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A luſty ſayle.

sp.speaker: Daugh.
sp.l: Look right, and look again.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: She plows the Sea before her,
And fomes i'th mouth.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: Of whence?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I ken not yet ſir.

sp.speaker: Seſs.
sp.l: O may ſhe prove of Naples.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Prove the Divell,
We'l ſpit out fire as thick as ſhe.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Hoy.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Brave boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Of Naples Naples, I think of Naples, Maſter,
Me thinks I ſee the Armes.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Up, up another,
And give more certain ſignes. Exit Saylor.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: All to your buſineſſe,
And ſtand but right and true▪

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: Hang him that halts now.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sh'as us in chaſe.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: We'l ſpare her our main top-ſaile,
He ſhall not look us long, we are no ſtarters,
Down with the fore-ſaile too, we'l ſpoom before her.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Gunner, good noble Gunner, for my honour
Load me but theſe two Minions in the chape there;
And load 'em right, that they may bid faire welcome,
And be thine eye and level as thy heart it.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Madam, Ile ſcratch 'em out, Ile piſſe 'em out elſe.

sp.speaker: Sayl. above.
sp.l: Ho.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Of whence now?

sp.speaker: Sayl.
sp.l: Of Naples, Naples, Naples.
I ſee her top flag how ſhe quarters Naples.
I heare her Trumpets.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Down, ſhe's welcome to us. Exit Maſt. Botſ. Gun. Sayl.
Every man to his charge, man her i'th bowe wel.
And place your rakers right, daughter be ſparing.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I ſweare Ile be above ſir, in the thickeſt,
And where moſt danger is, Ile ſeek for honour.
They have begun, harke how their Trumpets call us.
Hark how the wide mouth'd Cannons ſing amongſt us.
Heark how they ſaile; out of our ſhels for ſhame ſir.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Now fortune and my cauſe.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Be bold and conquer. Exit.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: They'l board us once again, they'r tuffe & valiant.

sp.speaker: Boteſ.
sp.l: Twice we have blown 'em into th'ayre like feathers.
And made 'em dance.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Good boys, fight bravely, manly. Enter Gunner.
They come on yet; clap in her ſtern, & yoke 'em.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: You ſhall not need, I have proviſion for 'em;
Let 'em boord once again, the next is ours.
Stand bravely to your Pikes, away, be valiant.
I have a ſecond courſe of ſervice for 'em,
Shall make the bowels of their Barke ake, hoy
The Duke fights like a Dragon. Who dares be idle. Exit. Charge, Trumpets, pieces goe off.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Down with 'em, ſtow 'em in.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: Cut their throats, tis brotherhood to fling em into the Sea.
The Duke is hurt, ſo is his lovely daughter Martia.
We have the day yet. Enter Gunner.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.p: Pox fire'em, they have ſmok'd us, never ſuch plumbs yet flew.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: They have rent the ſhip, & bor'd a hundred holes,
She ſwims ſtill luſtily.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: She made a brave fight, and he ſhall be cur'd,
And make a braver yet.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.p: Bring us ſome Cans up, I am hot as fire. Enter Boy with 3 Cans.

sp.speaker: Boteſ.
sp.l: I am ſure I am none o'th cooleſt.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: My Cannons rung like Bels. Here's to my Miſtris.
The dainty Sweet braſſe Minion, ſplit their fore-maſt,
She never failed.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Ye did all well, and truly, like faithfull honeſt men.

sp.speaker: Boteſ.
sp.p: But is ſhe rich Maſter? Trumpet flouriſh.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Rich for my Captains purpoſe howſoever,
And we are his. - How bravely now he ſhows,
Heated in blood and anger? how do you ſir?
Not wounded mortally I hope?

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: No Maſter, but onely weare the livery of fury.
I am hurt, and deep.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: My Miſtris too?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: A ſcratch man,
My needle would ha done as much good ſir,
Be provident and carefull.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Prethee peace girle,
This wound is not the firſt blood I have bluſht in,
Ye fought all like tall men, my thanks among ye,
That ſpeaks not what my purſe means, but my tongue, ſouldiers.
Now ſir, to you that ſought me out, that found me,
That found me what I am, the Tyrants Tyrant;
You that were imp'd the weak arme to his folly,
You are welcome to your death.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I do expect it,
And therefore need no complement, but waite it.

sp.speaker: Seſs.
sp.l: Thou bor'ſt the face once of a Noble Gentleman,
Rankt in the firſt file of the vertuous,
By every hopefull ſpirit, ſhewed and pointed,
Thy Countries love; one that advanc'd her honour,
Not taynted with the baſe and ſervile uſes
The Tyrant ties mens ſoules too. Tell me Ʋirolet,
If ſhame have not forſook thee, with thy credit.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: No more of theſe Racks; what I am I am.
I hope not to go free with poore confeſſions;
Nor if I ſhow ill, will I ſeem a monſter,
By making my mind priſoner; do your worſt.
When I came out to deale with you, I caſt it,
Onely thoſe baſe inflictions fit for ſlaves,
Becauſe I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Thou art none.
Thou waſt while thou ſtoodſt good, th'art now a villain
And agent for the divell.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: That tongue lies.
Give me my Sword again, and ſtand all arm'd;
He prove it on ye all, I am a Gentleman,
A man as faire in honour; rate your priſoners;
How poore and like a Pedagogue it ſhews?
How far from Nobleneſſe? tis fair, you may kil's;
But to defame your victory with foule language.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Go, fling him overboord; Ile teach you ſirra.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: You cannot teach me to die. I could kill you now
With patience, in deſpiſing all your cruelties.
And make you choke with anger.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Away I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay ſir, h'as given you ſuch bold language,
I am not reconcil'd to him yet, and therefore
He ſhall not have his wiſh obſerv'd ſo neerly,
To die when he pleaſe; I beſeech you ſtay ſir.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Do with him what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Carry him to th'Bilboes,
And clap him faſt there, with the Prince.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Do Lady,
For any death you give, I am bound to bleſſe you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now to your Cabin, ſir; pray lean upon me,
And take your reſt, the Surgeons waite all for you.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Thou makeſt me bluſh to ſee thee bear thy fortuns;
Why, ſure I have no hurt, I have not fought ſure?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: You bleed apace, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Ye grow cold too.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: I muſt be ruld, no leaning,
My deepeſt wounds ſcorn Crutches.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: A brave Generall. Flor. Trumpets, Cornets.

sp.speaker: 1 Sayl.
sp.l: Will they not moore her?

sp.speaker: 2 Sayl.
sp.l: Not till we come to the Fort,
This is too weak a place for our defences,
The Carpenters are hard at worke; ſhe ſwims well,
And may hold out another fight. The ſhip we took
Burns there to give us light.

sp.speaker: 1 Sayl.
sp.l: She made a brave fight.

sp.speaker: 2 Sayl.
sp.l: She put us all in feare.

sp.speaker: 1 Sayl.
sp.l: Beſhrew my heart did ſhe.
Her men are gone to Candy, they are pepper'd,
All but this priſoner.

sp.speaker: 2 Sayl.
sp.l: Sure he's a brave fellow.

sp.speaker: 1 Say.
sp.l: A ſtubborn knave, but we have pul'd his bravery.
sp.stage: He diſcovers Virolet and Aſcanio in the Bilboes.
sp.l: Look how he looks now: come let's go ſerve his dyet,
Which is but bread and water.

sp.speaker: 2 Sayl.
sp.l: He'l grow fat on't. Exeunt Saylors.

sp.speaker: Aſcan.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe I have endured much miſery,
even almoſt to the ruine of my ſpirit,
But ten times more grows my affliction,
To finde my friend here.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Had we ſerv'd our Countrey,
Or honeſties, as we have ſerv'd our follies,
We had not been here now?

sp.speaker: Aſcan.
sp.l: Tis to true Virolet.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: And yet my end in ventring for your ſafety,
Pointed at more then Ferrants will, a baſe one;
Some ſervice for mine own, ſome for my Nation,
Some for my friend; but I am rightly payd,
That durſt adventure ſuch a Noble office,
From the moſt treacherous command of miſchiefe;
You know him now?

sp.speaker: Aſcan.
sp.l: And when I neerer knew him,
Then when I waited, Heaven be witneſſe with me,
(And if I lie my miſeries ſtill load me)
With what teares I have woed him, with what prayers,
What weight of reaſons I have layd, what dangers;
Then, when the peoples curſes flew like ſtorms;
And every tongue was whetted to defame him,
To leave his doubts, his tyrannies, his ſlaughters,
His fell oppreſſions. I know I was hated too.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: And all mankind that knew him: theſe confeſſi|ons
Do no good to the world, to Heaven they may.
Let's ſtudy to die well, we have liv'd like coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Aſcan.
sp.l: That my miſ-fortune, ſhould loſe you too.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Yes;
And not onely me, but many more, and better:
For my life, tis not this; or might I ſave yours,
And ſome brave friends I have engag'd, let me go;
It were the meritorious death I wiſh for,
But we muſt hang or drown like whelps.

sp.speaker: Aſcan.
sp.l: No remedy.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: On my part I expect none. I know the man,
And know he has been netled to the quick too,
I know his nature.

sp.speaker: Aſcan.
sp.l: A moſt cruell nature.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: His wrongs have bred him up. I cannot blame him.

sp.speaker: Aſcan.
sp.l: He has a daughter too, the greateſt ſcorner,
And moſt inſulter upon miſery.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: For thoſe, they are toyes to laugh at, not to lead men:
A womans mirth or anger, like a meteor
Glides and is gone, and leaves no crack behind it;
Our miſeries would ſeem like maſters to us,
And ſhake our manly ſpirits into feavors,
If we reſpected thoſe; the more they glory,
And raiſe inſulting Trophies on our ruines;
The more our vertues ſhine in patience.
Sweet Prince, the name of death was never terrible
To him that knew to live; nor the loud torrent
Of all afflictions, ſinging as they ſwim,
A gall of heart, but to a guilty conſcience:
Whilſt we ſtand faire, but by a two-edg'd ſtorm,
We find untimely fals, like early Roſes;
But to the earth, we beare our native ſweetneſſe.

sp.speaker: Aſcan.
sp.l: Good ſir go on.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: When we are little children,
And cry and fret for every toy comes croſſe us;
How ſweetly do we ſhew, when ſleep ſteales on us?
When we grow great, but our affections greater,
And ſtruggle with this ſtubborn twin, born with us;
And tug and pull, yet ſtill we finde a Giant:
Had we not then the priviledge to ſleep,
Our everlaſting ſleep? he would make us ideots;
The memory and monuments of good men
Are more then lives, and tho their Tombs want tongues,
Yet have they eyes, that daily ſweat their loſſes;
And ſuch a teare from ſtone, no time can value.
To die both young and good, are natures curſes,
As the world ſays; ask truth, they are bountious bleſſings:
For then we reach at Heaven, in our full vertues,
And fix our ſelves new Stars, crown'd with our goodnes.

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: You have double arm'd me. Srange Muſick within, Hoboys.
Hark, what noyſe is this?
What horrid noyſe is the Sea pleas'd to ſing,
A hideous Dirg to our deliverance?

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.p: Stand faſt now. Within ſtrange cries, horrid noyſe, Trumpets.

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: I am fixt.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: We feare ye not. Enter Martia
Let death appear in all ſhapes, we ſmile on him.

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: The Lady now.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: The face oth' Maske is alter'd.

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: What will ſhe doe?

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Do what ſhe can, I care not.

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: She looks on you ſir.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Rather ſhe looks through me,
But yet ſhe ſtirs me not.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Poore wretched ſlaves,
Why do you live? or if ye hope for mercy,
Why do not you houle out, and fill the hold
With lamentations, cries, and baſe ſubmiſſions,
Worthy our ſcorn?

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Madam, you are miſtaken;
We are no ſlaves to you, but to blind fortune;
And if ſhe had her eyes, and durſt be certain,
Certain our friend, I would not bow unto her;
I would not cry, nor aske ſo baſe a mercy:
If you ſee any thing, in our appearance,
Worthy your ſexes ſoftnes and your own glory?
Do it for that; and let that good reward it:
We cannot beg.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Ile make you beg, and bow too.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Madam for what?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: For life; and when you hope it,
Then will I laugh and triumph on your baſeneſſe.

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: Madam tis true, there may be ſuch a favour,
And we may aske it too; aske it with honour;
And thanke you for that favour, nobly thank you,
Tho it be death; but when we beg a baſe life,
And beg it of your ſcorn—

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Y'are couzened woman,
Your handſomneſſe may do much, but not this way;
But for your glorious hate—

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Are ye ſo ſtubborn?
Death, I will make you bow.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: It muſt be in your bed then;
There you may worke me to humility.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Why, I can kill thee.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: If you do it handſomely;
It may be I can thank you, elſe—

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: So glorious?

sp.speaker: Aſca.
sp.l: Her cruelty now workes.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Yet woot thou?

sp.speaker: Virt.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Wilt thou for life ſake?

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: No, I know your ſubtilty.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: For honour ſake?

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: I will not be a Pageant,
My mind was ever firm, and ſo Ile loſe it.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Ile ſtarve thee to it.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Ile ſtarve my ſelfe, and croſſe it.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Ile lay thee on ſuch miſeries—

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Ile weare 'em,
And with that wantonneſſe, you do your Bracelets.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Ile be a moneth a killing thee.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Poore Lady,
Ile be a moneth a dying then: what's that?
There's many a Callenture outdoes your cruelty.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: How might I do, in killing of his body,
To ſave his Noble mind? Who waites there?

div.stage: Enter a Saylor with a rich Cap and Mantle.

sp.speaker: Sayl.
sp.l: Maddam.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Unbolt this man, and leave thoſe things behind you,
And ſo away. Now put 'em on. Uunbolt him. Exit Sailor.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: To what end?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: To my end, to my will.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Nay, now you thank me, Ile do more. Ile tell ye,
I am a ſervant to your curteſie,
And ſo far will be wooed: but if this triumph
Be onely aym'd, to make your miſchiefe glorious;
Lady, y'ave put a richer ſhroud upon me,
Which my ſtrong mind ſhall ſuffer in.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Come hither,
And all thy bravery put into thy carriage,
For I admire thee.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Whither will this woman?

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: Take heed my friend.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Look as thou ſcorndſt my cruelty:
I know thou doeſt.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I never fear'd, nor flatter'd.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: No if thou hadſt, thou hadſt died, & I had gloried.
I ſuffer now, and thou which art my priſoner,
Haſt Nobly won the free power to deſpiſe me.
I love thee, and admire thee for thy Nobleneſſe;
And for thy manly ſufferance, am thy ſervant.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Good Lady, mock me not.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: By Heaven I love thee;
And by the ſoule of love, am one piece with thee.
Thy mind, thy mind; thy brave, thy manly mind:
That like a Rock ſtands all the ſtorms of fortune,
And beats 'em roaring back they cannot reach thee:
That lovely mind I dote on, not the body;
That mind has rob'd me of my liberty:
That mind has darken'd all my bravery,
And into poor deſpiſ'd things, turn'd my angers.
Receive me to your love ſir, and inſtruct me;
Receive me to your bed, and marry me:
Ile wait upon you, bleſſe the houre I knew you.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Is this a new way?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: If you doubt my faith▪
Firſt take your liberty; Ile make it perfect,
Or any thing within my power.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: I love you;
But how to recompence your love with marriage?
Alas, I have a wife.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Dearer then I am?
That will adventure ſo much for your ſafety?
Forget her fathers wrongs, quit her own honour,
Pull on her for a ſtrangers ſake, all curſes?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Shall this Prince have his freedom too?
Elſe all I love is gone, all my friends periſh.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: He ſhall.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: If thou deſpiſe my curteſie,
When I am dead, for griefe I am forſaken,
And no ſoft hand left to aſſwage your ſorrows;
Too late, but too true, curſe your own cruelties.

sp.speaker: Aſcan.
sp.l: Be wiſe; if ſhe be true, no thred is left elſe,
To guide us from this laborinth of miſchiefe;
Nor no way for our friends.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Thus then, I take you:
I bind ye to my life, my love.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I take you,
And with the like bond tye my heart your ſervant;
W'are now almoſt at Harbour, within this houre,
In the dead watch, Ile have the long boat ready;
And when I give the word, be ſure you enter,
Ile ſee ye furniſht both immediately,
And like your ſelfe; ſome truſty man ſhall wait you,
The watch Ile make mine own; onely my love
Requires a ſtronger vow, which Ile adminiſter
Before we go.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: Ile take it to confirm you.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Go in, there are the Keys, unlock his fetters,
And arme ye Nobly both; Ile be with you preſently,
And ſ● this loving kiſſe.

sp.speaker: Aſ●●n.
sp.l: Be conſtant Lady. Exeunt omnes.

div.stage: Enter the Duke of Seſſe by Torchlight, Maſter and Surgeon, with him.

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.l: You grow ſo angry ſir, your wound goes back|ward.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: I am angry at the time, at none of you,
That ſends but one poor ſubject for revenge;
I would have all the Court, and all the villany,
Was ever practiz'd under that foule Ferrand
Tyrant, and all to quench my wrath.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Be patient,
Your grace may find occaſion every houre,
For certaine they will ſeeke you, to ſatisfy,
And to the full, your anger.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Death, they dare not:
They know that I command death, feed his hunger,
And when I let him looſe—

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.l: You'l never heale ſir,
If theſe extreames dwell in you, you are old,
And burn your ſpirits out with this wild angers.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Thou lieſt, I am not old, I am as luſty
And full of manly heat as them, or thou art.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: No more of that.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: And dare ſeek out a danger;
And hold him at the ſwords point, when thou trembleſt
And creepeſt into thy box of ſalves to ſave thee.
O Maſter, I have had a dreadfull dream to night!
Me-thought the ſhip was all on fire, and my lov'd Daughter,
To ſave her life, leapt into th' Sea; where ſuddainly
A ſtranger ſnatch'd her up, and ſwom away with her.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.p: 'Twas but the heate o'th fight ſir. Boateſwain within & Sailor.

sp.speaker: Boteſ.
sp.l: Look out, what's that?

sp.speaker: Sail.
sp.l: The long bote as I live.

sp.speaker: Bote.
sp.p: Ho, there, ith long Bote. She claps on all her Oares.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: What noiſe is that? Hoy.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: I hear ſir — Exit Maſter.

sp.speaker: Boatſ.
sp.l: The devill or his dam; haile her agen boyes.

sp.speaker: Sſail.
sp.l: The long boate, ho, the long boate.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Why, the long boate?
Where is the long Boate?

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: She is ſtolne off. En. Maſter.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Who ſtole her?
O my prophetique ſoule!

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Your daughter's gone ſir;
The priſoners, and ſix Saylors, rogues.

sp.speaker: Seſ
sp.l: Miſchief, ſix thouſand plagues ſale with 'em;
They'r in her yet, make out.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: We have ne'r a Boate. En. Gunner.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Who knew of this trick?

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Weigh Anchors and away.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: We ha' no winde ſir,
They'l beate us with their Oares.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Then ſinke 'em Gunner,
O ſink 'em, ſink 'em, ſink 'em, claw 'em Gunner;
As ever thou haſt lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: I'le do reaſon,
But i'le be hangd before I hurt the Lady. Exit Gun.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.p: Who knew of this? Trump. a peece or two go off.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: We ſtand all clear.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: What divel
Put this baſe trick into her tayle? my daughter,
And run away with rogues! I hope ſhe's ſunk, A peece or two.
Or torne to pieces with the ſhot; rots find her,
The leproſy of whore, ſtick ever to her, En. Gunner.
O ſhe has ruind my revenge.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: She is gone ſir,
I cannot reach her with my ſhot.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Riſe winds, blow till you burſt the aire,
Blow till ye burſt the aire, and ſwell the Seas,
That they may ſink the ſtarres, O dance her, dance her;
Shes impudently wanton, dance her, dance her,
Mount her upon your ſurges, coole her, coole her
She runs hot like a whore, coole her, coole her;
O now a ſhot to ſink her; come, cut Cables;
I will away, and where ſhe ſets her foote
Although it be in Ferrants court, ile follow her,
And ſuch a fathers vengeance ſhall ſhe ſuffer—
Dare any man ſtand by me?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: All, all.

sp.speaker: Boatſ.
sp.l: All ſir.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: And the ſame cup you taſte.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Cut Cables then;
For I ſhall never ſleep, nor know what peace is,
Till I have pluckt her heart out;

sp.speaker: All within.
sp.l: O maine there. Exeunt.

div.head: Scoena prima.
div.stage: Enter Ferrant, Ronvere, Caſtruchio, Villo, and Guard.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: You are too gentle ſir. Floriſh cornets.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You are too careleſſe:
The creatures I have made, no way regard me:
VVhy ſhould I give you names, titles of honour
Rob families, to fill your private houſes
For your advancement, draw all curſes on me,
VVake tedious winter nights, to make them happy
That for me break no ſlumber?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: VVhat we can,
VVe dare doe

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: VVhy is your Soveraignes life then
(In which you live, and in whoſe fall your honours,
Your wealth, your pomp, your pride and all muſt ſuffer)
No better guarded? O my cruell Stars,
That marke me out a King, raiſing me on
This pinnacle of greatneſſe, only to be
The neerer blaſting!

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: VVhat think you now Caſtruchio?
Is not this a merry life?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Still thou art couzend;
It is a glorious royall diſcontentment;
How bravely it becomes him!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: To be made
The common butt, for every ſlave to ſhoot at;
No peace, no reſt I take, but their alarams
Beat at my heart: why do I live, or ſeek then,
To adde a day more to theſe glorious troubles?
Or to what end when all I can arrive at,
Is but the ſumming up of feares and ſorrowes,
VVhat power has my command, when from my boſom
Aſcanio my moſt dear, and lov'd Aſcanio,
Was ſnatch'd, ſpite of my wil, ſpite of my ſuccor,
And by mine own proud ſlave reteind moſt miſerable?
And ſtill that villains lives to nip my pleaſures,
It being not within my power to reach him.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Time may reſtore all this; and would you hear
VVhoſe counſell never faild you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Tell me no more,
I faint beneath the burthen of my cares,
And yeild my ſelfe moſt wretched.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: On my Knees
I beg it might ſir, vouchſafe me hearing.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Speak, ſpeak, and I thus low, ſuch is my fortune,
VVill hear what thou canſt ſay.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Look but on this,
Has not a man that has but means to keep
A Hawk, a Grayhound, and a hunting Nag,
More pleaſure then this King?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: A dull foole ſtill,
Make me a King, and let me ſcratch with care,
And ſee who'l have the better; give me rule,
Command, obedience, pleaſure of a King,
And let the devil rore; The greateſt corroſive
A King can have, is of more pretious tickling,
And handled to the height more dear delight,
Then other mens whole lives, let 'em be ſafe too.

sp.speaker: Ʋil.
sp.l: Think of the mutinous people.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Hang the people,
Give me the pleaſure, let me do all, awe all,
Enjoy their wives and ſtates at my diſcretion,
And peg 'em when I pleaſe, let the ſlaves mumble.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: But ſay they ſhould be vex'd, and riſe againſt thee?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Let 'em riſe, let 'em riſe: give me the bridle here,
And ſee if they can crack my girths: ah Villio,
Under the Sun, ther's nothing ſo voluptuous
As riding of this monſter, till he founder.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: VVho's that ſo low●?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I am dumb: is not this rare?
Kings looks make Pythagoreans; is not this
A happineſſe Villio?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Yes, to put to ſilence
A fawning ſycophant.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thou ſpeak'ſt truth in all,
And mercy is a vice, when there needs rigour,
VVhich I with all ſeverity will practiſe;
And ſince as ſubjects they pay not obedience.
They ſhall be forc'd as ſlaves: I wil remove
Their meanes to hurt, and with the means, my fears:
Goe you the fatall executioners
Of my commands, and in our name proclame,
That from this houre I do forbid all meetings,
All private conferences in the City:
To feaſt a neighbour ſhall be death; to talke,
As they meete in the ſtreetes, to hold diſcourſe,
By writing, nay by ſignes; ſee this perform'd,
And I wil call your cruelty, to thoſe
That dare repine at this, to me true ſervice.

sp.speaker: 1 Gard.
sp.l: This makes for us.

sp.speaker: 2. Gard.
sp.l: I now we have imployments,
If we grow not rich 'twere fit we ſhould be beggers.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Thou enemy to Majeſty?
VVhat think'ſt thou of a Kingdome?

sp.speaker: Ʋil.
sp.l: As of a man
That hath power to doe ill.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Of a thing rather
That does divide an Empire with the Gods;
Obſerve but with how little breath he ſhakes
A populous City, which would ſtand unmov'd
Againſt a whirlewind.

sp.speaker: Ʋil.
sp.l: Then you make him more
Then him that rules the winds.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: For me I doe profeſſe it,
Were I offerd to be any thing on Earth,
I would be mighty Ferrant.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ha? who names me?
Deliver thy thoughts ſlave, thy thoughts, and truly,
Or be no more.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: They rather will deſerve.
Your favour then your fury; I admire,
(As who does not, that is a loyall ſubject?)
Your wiſdom, power, your perfect happineſſe,
The moſt bleſt of mankind.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Didſt thou but feele
The weighty ſorrowes, that ſit on a Crown,
Tho thou ſhouldſt find one in the ſtreets Caſtruchio,
Thou wouldſt not think it worth the taking up;
But ſince thou art enamour'd of my fortune,
Thou ſhalt ere long taſte of it.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: But one day,
And then let me expire.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Goe to my wardrop,
And of the richeſt things I wear, cull out,
What thou thinkſt fit: do you attend him ſirra.

sp.speaker: Ʋil.
sp.l: I warrant you, I ſhall be at his elbow,
The foole wil never leave him. Exit Caſt. Ʋillio.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Made for ever. A ſhout within.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What ſhout is that? draw up Guards.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Thoſe rather En. Ʋirolet, Aſcanio, and a ſervant.
Speake joy then danger.
Bring her to my houſe,
I would not have her ſeen here.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My Aſcanio!
The moſt deſir'd of all the men, let me die
In theſe embraces; how wert thou redeem'd?

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: Sir, this is my preſerver.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: At more leaſure,
I will inquire the manner, and the meanes,
I cannot ſpare ſo much time now from my
More ſtrickt embraces: Ʋirolet, welcome too,
This ſervice weighes down your entended treaſon;
You long have bin mine enemy, learn now
To be my friend and loyall, I aske no more,
And live as free as Ferrant; let him have
The forty thouſand crowns I gladly promis'd,
For my Aſcanios freedom, and deliver
His Father, and his wife to him in ſafety,
Something hath paſſed which I am ſorry for,
But 'twill not now be help'd; come my Aſcanio,
And reap the harveſt of my winter travels. Floriſh Cornets. Exit Fer. Aſcanio.
My beſt Aſcanio, my moſt lov'd Aſcanio.

sp.speaker: Ʋiro.
sp.l: My Lord, all former paſſages forgot,
I am become a ſuitor.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: To me Ʋirolet?

sp.speaker: Ʋirol.
sp.l: To you, yet will not beg the courteſie,
But largely pay you for it.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: To the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Ʋirol.
sp.l: The forty thouſand crownes the King hath given me,
I will beſtow on you, if by your meanes
I may have liberty for a divorce
Between me and my wife.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Your Julicana?
That for you hath indur'd ſo much, ſo nobly?

sp.speaker: Ʋirol.
sp.l: The more my ſorrow; but it muſt be ſo.

sp.speaker: Ron
sp.l: I will not hinder it: without a bribe,
For mine own ends, I would have further'd this.
I will uſe all my power.

sp.speaker: Ʋirol.
sp.l: 'Tis all I aske:
Oh my curs'd fate, that ever man ſhould hate
Himſelfe for being belov'd, or be compeld
To caſt away a Jewell, Kings would buy,
Tho with the loſſe of Crown and Monarchy! Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: How do I look?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: You are ſo ſtrangely alterd,
We ſcarce can know you, ſo young againe, and utterly
From that you were, figure, or any favour▪
Your friends cannnot diſcern you.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: I have none,
None but my faire revenge, and let that know me▪
You are finely alterd too.

sp.speaker: Boatſ.
sp.l: To pleaſe your humour,
But we may paſſe without diſguiſe, our living
Was never in their element.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: This Jew ſure,
That alter'd you, is a made knave.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: O! a moſt excellent fellow.

sp.speaker: Gun,
sp.l: How he has mew'd your head, has rub'd the ſhow off,
And run your beard into a peak of twenty!

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: Stopt all the crannies in your face.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Moſt rarely.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: And now you look as plump, your eyes as ſpark|ling,
As if you were to leap into a Ladies ſaddle.
Has he not ſet your noſe awry?

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: The better.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: I think it be the better, but tis awry ſure;
North and by Eaſt. I ther's the point it ſtands in;
Now halfe a point to th'Southward.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: I could laugh,
But that my buſineſſe requires no mirth now;
Thou art a merry fellow.

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: I would the Jew ſir,
Could ſteer my head right, for I have ſuch a ſwimming in't,
Ever ſince I went to Sea firſt.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Take wine and purg it.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: I have had a thouſand pils of Sack, a thouſand;
A thouſand pottle pils.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Take more.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: Good Doctor, En. Citizens, ſeverally.
Your patient is eaſily perſwaded.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: The next faire open weather
Me thinks this Jew,
If he were truly known to founder'd Courtiers,
And decaied Ladies, that have loſt their fleeces
On every buſh, he might pick a pretty living.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: The beſt of all our gallants, now be glad of him;
For if you marke their marches, they are tender,
Soft, ſoft, and tender; then but obſerve their bodies,
And you ſhall find 'em cemented by a Surgeon,
Or ſome Phyſitian for a year or two,
And then toth'tub again, for a new pickle.
This Jew might live a Gentile here. En. 2. Citizens at both dores, ſa|luting afar off.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: What are theſe?
Stand cloſe and marke?

sp.speaker: Boat.
sp.l: Theſe are no men, th'are motions.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: What ſad and ruthfull faces!

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: How they duck!
This ſenceleſſe, ſilent courteſie me thinks,
Shewes like two Turkes, ſalu●ing one another,
Upon two French porters backs.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: They are my Countrymen,
And this, ſome forc'd infliction from the tyrant;
What are you? why is this? why move thus ſilent
As if you were wandring ſhadowes? why ſo ſad?
Your tongues ſeald up; are yee of ſeverall Countries?
You underſtand not one another?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: That's an Engliſh man,
He lookes as though he had loſt his dog.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Your habits
Shew ye all Neapolitanes, and your faces
Deliver you oppreſſed things: ſpeak boldly:
Do you groan, and labor under this ſtiffe yoak?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: They ſhake their heads and weep.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: O miſery!
Give plenteous ſorrow, and no tongues to ſhew 'em!
This is a ſtudied cruelty.

sp.speaker: 1. Citi.
sp.l: Be gon ſir,
It ſeemes you are a ſtranger and your ſelfe;

sp.speaker: 2. Citi.
sp.l: You wonder here at us, as much we wonder
To hear you ſpeak ſo openly, and boldly,
The Kings command being publiſht to the contrary;
Tis death here, above two to talk together;
And that muſt be but common ſalutation neither,
Short and ſo part.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: How ſhould a man buy muſtard,
If he be forc'd to ſtay the making of it?
Cleare all the ſtreetes before the King:

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.l: Get off Sir,
And ſhift as we muſt do. Exeunt Citizens

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: I'le ſee his glory.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.p: Stand faſt now and like men, Flouriſh colours.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Begin the game ſir, En. Caſtrucrio like the King, in the midſt of a gard. Ʋillio.
And pluck me down, the Row
Of houſes there.
They hide the view oth' hill; and ſink thoſe merchants,
Their ſhips are foule and ſtinke.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: This is a ſweete youth.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: All that are taken in aſſemblies,
Their houſes and their wives, their wealthes are foreit,
Their lives at your devotion. Villaines, Knaves,
I'le make you bow & ſhake, i'le make you kneele Rogues.
How brave tis to be a King?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Here's fine tumbling.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: No man ſhall ſit i'th' temple neer another.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: Nor lie with his own wife.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: All upon paine
Of preſent death, forget to write.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: That's excellent,
Carriers and foot-Poſts, wil be arrant Rebels.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: No Character, or ſtamp that may deliver
This mans intention, to that man i'th' Country.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Nay, an you cut off, after my hearty commenda|tions
Your friend and Oliver. No more.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: No man ſmile,
And wear a face of mirth; that fellowes comming,
And hides a double heart, he's your prize, ſmoke him.

div.stage: Enter Ʋirolet, Ronvero, Aſcanio, and Martia, Paſſing over.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: What baſe abuſe is this? Ha? tis her face ſure,
My priſoners with her too? by heaven wild whore
Now is my time.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Do what you will.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Stay hold yet,
My Country ſhall be ſerv'd firſt, let her go,
Wee'l have an hour for her to make her tremble.
Now ſhew your ſelves, and bleſſe you with your valors.

sp.speaker: Guard
sp.p: Here's a whole plump of Rogues. Ʋirolet and they off againe.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Now for your Country.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Away with 'em and hang 'em; no, no mercy,
I ſay no mercy.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Be it ſo upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Treaſon, treaſon, treaſon.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: Cut the ſlaves to giggets.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Down with the bul-beefes.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Hold, hold, I command you—look here

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: A miſerable thing. I am no King ſir.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Sirra, your fooles face has preſerv'd your life.
Wear no more Kings coates, you have ſcap'd a ſcouring.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: I'ſt not the King.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: No, tis a prating Raſcall,
The puppy makes him mirth.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Yes ſir, I am a puppy.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: I beſeech you let me hang him,
I'le do't in my belt ſtraight.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: As you are honorable,
It is enough you may hang me.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: I'le hang a ſquib at's taile
That ſhall blow both his buttocks, like a petar.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Do any thing.
But do not kill me Gentlemen. Enter Citizen.

sp.speaker: Boate.
sp.l: Lets flea h●m, and have him flye blowen.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Away, and ſave your lives.
The King himſelfe is conning on▪ if you ſtay,
You are loſt for ever; let not ſo much nobleneſſe
Willfully periſh.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: How neer?

sp.speaker: 2. Citiz.
sp.p: He's here behind you. Ex. Seſſ. Boatſw. Saylers, Citizens.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: We thank you. vaniſh.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Double the Guards and take in men that dare,
Theſe ſlaves are frighted; where are the proud Rebels,
To what protection fled, what villain leads 'em?
Under our noſe diſturb our reſt?

sp.speaker: Ronver.
sp.l: We ſhall heare,
For ſuch a ſearch I have ſent, to hunt the Traytors.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Yet better men I ſay, we ſtand too open:
How now Caſtruchio? how do you like our glory?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe, 'twas ſomewhat more then my match Sir;
This open glory agrees not with my body,
But if it were ith' Caſtle, or ſome ſtrength,
Where I might have my ſwing.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: You have been ſwing'd brother;
How theſe delights have tickled you? you itch yet;
Will you walke out again in pomp?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Good Foole.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Theſe rogues muſt be rebuked, they are too ſawcy,
Theſe peremptory Knaves. Will you walk out Sir,
And take the remnant of your Coronation?
The people ſtay to ſee it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Do not vex him;
Ha's griefe enough in's bones; you ſhall to th' Citadell,
And like my ſelfe command, there uſe your pleaſure,
But take heed to your perſon.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: The more danger;
Still the more honour Brother.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: If I reign not then,
And like a King, and thou ſhalt know it fool,
And thou ſhalt feel it foole.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Fooles ſtill are freemen,
I'le ſue for a protection, till thy reigne's out.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The people have abus'd the liberty
I late allowed, I now proclaime it ſtraighter,
No men ſhall walk together, nor ſalute;
For they that doe ſhall dye.

sp.speaker: Ronver.
sp.l: You hit the right Sir;
That liberty cut off, you are free from practiſe.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Renew my guards.

sp.speaker: Ronver.
sp.l: I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And keep ſtrict watches;
One houre of joy I aske.

sp.speaker: Ronver.
sp.l: You ſhall have many. Exeunt. Flor. Cor.

div.stage: Pandulfo, and Iuliana, led by two of the guard, as not yet fully recover'd.

sp.speaker: 1. Guard.
sp.l: You are now at liberty, in your own houſe Lady,
And here our charge takes end.

sp.speaker: Pandul.
sp.l: 'Tis now a Cuſtome.
We muſt even wooe thoſe men deſerve worſt of us,
And ſo we thanke your labours; there's to drinke,
For that, and miſchiefe are your occupations;
And to meane well to no man, you Chief'ſt harveſts.

sp.speaker: 2. Gard.
sp.l: You give liberally; we hope Sir, er't be long,
To be oftner acquainted with your bounty,
And ſo we leave you.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Doe, for I dote not on ye;

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: But where's my Husband? what ſhould I do here?
Or what ſhare have I in this joy, cal'd liberty,
Without his company? Why did you flatter me,
And tell me he was return'd, his ſervice honour'd?

sp.speaker: 1. Gard.
sp.l: He is ſo, and ſtands high in the Kings favour,
His friends redeemd, and his own liberty,
From which yours is deriv'd, confirm'd; his ſervice,
To his own wiſh rewarded: ſo fare-well Lady. Ex. Guard.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Go perſecute the good, and hunt ye hell-hounds;
Ye Leeches of the time, ſuck till ye burſt ſlaves;
How does my girle?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Weake yet, but full of comfort;

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Sit down, and take ſome reſt;

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My heart's whole Father;
That joyes, and leaps, to heare my Virolet,
My Deer, my life, has conquer'd his afflictions.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Thoſe rude hands, and that bloody will that did this,
That durſt upon thy tender body Print
Theſe Characters of cruelty; heare me heaven.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O Sir be ſparing.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I'le ſpeake it, tho I burſt;
And tho the ayre had eares, and ſerv'd the Tyrant,
Out it ſhould goe: O heare me thou great Juſtice;
The miſeries, that waite upon their miſchiefs,
Let them be numberleſſe, and no eye pitty
Them when their ſoules are loaden, and in labour,
And wounded through, and through, with guilt & horror,
As mine is now with griefe; let men laugh at 'em
Then, when their monſtrous ſins, like earth-quaks, ſhake 'em;
And thoſe eyes, that forgot heaven would look upward,
The bloody 'larms, of the conſcience beating,
Let mercy flye, and day ſtrook into darkneſſe,
Leave their blind ſoules, to hunt out their own horrors.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Enough, enough, we muſt forget deare Father;
For then we are glorious formes of heaven; and live,
When we can ſuffer, and as ſoon forgive.
But where's my Lord? me thinkes I have ſeen this houſe,
And have been in't before.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Thine own houſe jewell.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Mine, without him? or his, without my company?
I thinke it cannot be; it was not wont Father.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Some buſineſſe with the King (let it be good heaven)
Reteines him ſure. Enter Boy.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: It muſt be good and noble,
For all men that he treats with taſte of vertue;
His words and actions are his own; and Honour's
Not bought, nor compel'd from him.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Here's the Boy.
He can confirme us more, how ſad the child looks?
Come hither Lucio; how, and where's thy Maſter?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Speak gentle Boy.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Is he return'd in ſafety?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: If not, and that thou knoweſt is miſerable,
Our hopes and happineſſe declin'd for ever;
Study a ſorrow, excellent as thy Maſter,
Then if thou canſt live, leave us.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: Noble Madam,
My Lord is ſafe return'd, ſafe to his friends, and fortune,
Safe to his Country, entertain'd with honour,
Is here within the houſe.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Doe not mock me.

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: But ſuch a melancholy hangs on his mind,
And in his eyes inhabit ſuch ſad ſhadowes;
But what the cauſe is—

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Goe tell him we are here Boy,
There muſt be no cauſe now.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Haſt thou forgot me?

sp.speaker: Lucio.
sp.l: No, nobleſt Lady.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tell him I am here,
Tell him his wife is here, ſound my name to him,
And thou ſhalt ſee him ſtart; ſpeake Iuliana,
And like the Sunne that labors through a tempeſt,
How ſuddainly he will diſperſe his ſadneſſe?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Goe I command thee inſtantly,
And charge him on his duty.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: On his Love Boy:
I would faine goe to him.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Away, away, you are fooliſh.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Beare all my ſervice ſweet Boy.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Art thou here ſtill?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And tell him what thou wilt that ſhall become thee.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Ith' houſe; and know we are here. Ex. Boy.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: No, no, he did not;
I warrant you he did not: could you think
His Love had leſſe then wings, had he but ſeen me;
His ſtrong affection any thing but fire
Conſuming all weak lets, and rubs before it,
Till he had met my flame, and made one body?
If ever heavens high bleſſings met in one man,
And there erected to their holy uſes▪
A ſacred mind, fit for their ſervices,
Built all of poliſht honour, 'twas in this man:
Miſdoubt him not.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I know he's truly noble;
But why this ſadneſſe, when the generall cauſe
Requires a Jubile of joy?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I know not. Enter Virolet, and Boy.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Pray heaven you find it not.

sp.speaker: Jul
sp.l: I hope I ſhall not:
O here he comes, and with him all my happineſſe;
He ſtaies and thinks, we may be too unmannerly;
Pray give him leave. they ſtand off.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: I doe not like this ſadneſſe.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: O hard condition of my miſery!
Unheard of plagues! when to behold that woman,
That chaſte and vertuous woman, that preſerv'd me,
That pious wife, wedded to my afflictions,
Muſt be more terrible then all my dangers.
O fortune, thou haſt rob'd men of my making,
The noble building of a man, demoliſht,
And flung me headlong, on a ſin ſo baſe
Man and mankind contemn; even beaſts abhor it,
A ſin more dull then drinke, a ſhame beyond it;
So foule, and farre from faith; I dare not name it,
But it will cry it ſelf out, loud ingratitude.
Your bleſſing Sir.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: You have it in abundance;
So is our joy, to ſee you ſafe.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: My Deere one;

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: H'as not forgot me yet: O take me to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: Muſt this be added to increaſe my miſery,
