That ſhe muſt weep for joy, and looſe that goodneſſe?
My Iuliana, even the beſt of women,
Of wives the perfecteſt, let me ſpeak this,
And with a modeſty declare thy vertues,
Chaſter then Chriſtall, on the Scythian Clifts
The more the proud winds Court, the more the purer.
Sweeter in thy obedience, then a ſacrifice;
And in thy mind a Saint, that even yet living,
Produceſt miracles, and women daily
With crooked and tame ſoules creep to thy goodneſſe,
Which having toucht at, they become examples.
The fortitude of all their ſex, is Fable
Compar'd to thine; and they that fill'd up glory,
And admiration, in the age behind us,
Out of their celebrated urns, are ſtarted,
To ſtare upon the greatneſſe of thy ſpirit;
Wondring what new Martyr heaven has begot,
To fill the times with truth, and eaſe their ſtories:
Being all theſe, and excellent in beauty,
(For noble things dwell in the nobleſt buildings)
Thou haſt undone thy husband, made him wretch'ed,
A miſerable man, my Juliana,
Thou haſt made thy Ʋirolet.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Now goodneſſe keep me;
Oh! my dear Lord.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: She wrong you? what's the meaning?
Weep not, but ſpeake, I charge you on obedience;
Your Father charges you; ſhe make you miſerable?
That you your ſelf confeſſe.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: I doe, that kils me;
And far leſſe I have ſpoke her▪ then her merit.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: It is ſome ſinne of weakneſſe, or of Ignorance?
For ſure my Will—

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: No, 'tis a ſinne of excellence:
Forgive me heaven, that I prophane thy bleſſings:
Sit ſtill; I'le ſhew you all. Exit Ʋirolet.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: What meanes this madneſſe?
For ſure there is no taſte of right man in it;
Greives he our liberty, our preſervation?
Or has the greatneſſe of the deed he has done,
Made him forget, for whom, and how he did it,
And looking down upon us, ſcorne the benefit?
Well Ʋirolet if thou beeſt proud, or treacherous

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: He cannot Sir, he cannot; he will ſhew us,
And with that reaſon ground his words.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: He comes. Enter Ʋirolet, Martia, Ronver.
What Maſque is this? what admirable beauty?
Pray heaven his heart be true.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: A goodly woman.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: Tell me my Dear; and tell me without flattery,
As you are nobly honeſt, ſpeak the truth;
What thinke you of this Lady?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: She is moſt excellent.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: Might not this beauty tell me that it's a ſweet one,
Without more ſetting off, as now it is,
Thanking no greater Miſtreſſe then meer nature?
Stagger a conſtant heart?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: She is full of wonder;
But yet; yet Ʋirolet.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: Pray; by your leave Sir.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: She would amaze:

sp.speaker: Ʋir
sp.l: O! would ſhe ſo? I thanke you;
Say to this beauty, ſhe have all additions,
Wealth, noble birth.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: O hold there.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: All vertues,
A mind, as full of Candor as the truth is,
I, and a loving Lady.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: She muſt needs
(I am bound in conſcience to confeſſe) deſerve much.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: Nay, ſay beyond all theſe, ſhe be ſo pious,
That even on ſlaves condemn'd ſhe ſhowre her benefits,
And melt their ſtubborn Bolts with her ſoft pitty,
What thinke you then?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: For ſuch a noble office,
At theſe yeares, I ſhould dote my ſelf; take heed Boy,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If you be he, that have received theſe bleſſings,
And this the Lady: love her, honour her;
You cannot doe too much, to ſhew your gratitude,
Your greateſt ſervice will ſhew off too ſlender.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: This is the Lady; Lady of that bounty,
That wealth, that noble name, that all I ſpoke of:
The Prince Aſcaino and my ſelfe, the ſlaves
Redeem'd, brought home, ſtill guarded by her goodnes,
And of our liberties you taſte the ſweetnes;
Even you ſhe has preſerv'd too, lengthen'd your lives.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And what reward doe you purpoſe? it muſt be a maine one;
If love will do it we'll all, ſo love her, ſerve her.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: It muſt be my love.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Mine, my onely love,
My everlaſting love:

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Pray have patience.
The recompence ſhe ask'd, and I have render'd.
Was to become her husband: then I vowed it,
And ſince I have made it good.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Thou durſt not.

sp.speaker: Virol.
sp.l: Done Sir.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Be what you pleaſe, his happineſſe yet ſtayes with me,
You have been mine; Oh my unhappy fortune.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Nay, break and dye;

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: It cannot yet: I muſt live,
Till I ſee this man, bleſt in his new love,
And then:

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: What haſt thou done? thou baſe one tell me,
Thou barren thing of honeſty, and honour;
What haſt thou wrought? Is not this ſhe, looke on her,
Look on her, with the eyes of gratitude,
And whipe thy falſe teares off; Is not this ſhe,
That three times on the Rack, to guard thy ſafety,
When thou ſtood'ſt loſt, and naked to the Tyrant;
Thy aged Father here, that ſhames to know thee Tirant,
Ingag'd ith' jawes of danger; was not this ſhe,
That then gave up her body to the torture?
That tender body, that the wind ſings through;
And three times, when her ſinewes, crack'd & torter'd,
The beauties of her body turn'd to ruines,
Even then, within her patient heart, ſhe lock'd thee;
Then hid thee from the Tyrant; then preſerv'd thee;
And canſt thou be that ſlave?

sp.speaker: Martia.
sp.l: This was but duty;
She did it for her Husband, and ſhe ought it;
She has had the pleaſure of him, many an houre;
And if one minutes paine cannot be ſuffer'd;
Mine was above all theſe, a nobler venter,
I ſpeake it boldly, for I loſt a Father.
He has one ſtill; I left my friends, he has many;
Expos'd my life, and honour to a cruelty,
That if it had ſeiz'd on me, racks and tortures,
Alas, they are Triumphs to it: and had it hit,
For this mans love, it ſhould have ſhewed a triumph,
Twiſe loſt, I freed him; Roſſana loſt before him,
His fortunes with him; and his friends behind him:
Twiſe was I rack'd my ſelfe for his deliverance,
In honour firſt and name, which was a torture
The Hang-man never heard of; next at Sea,
In our eſcape, where the proud waves took pleaſure
To toſſe my little Boat up like a Bubble,
Then like meteor in the ayre he hung,
Then catcht, and hug him in the depth of darkneſſe;
The Canon from my incenſed Fathers Ship,
Ringing our Knell, and ſtill as we peep'd upward,
Beating the raging ſurge, with fire and Bullet,
And I ſtood fixt for this mans ſake, and ſcorn'd it;
Compare but this:

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: 'Tis too true; O my fortune!
That I muſt equally be bound to either:

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: You have the better, and the nobler Lady;
And now I am forc'd, a lover of her goodneſſe.
And ſo far have you wrought for his deliverance,
That is my Lord, ſo lovingly and nobly,
That now me thinks I ſtagger in my Title.
But how with honeſty? for I am poor Lady,
In all my dutious ſervice but your ſhadow,
Yet would be juſt; how with faire fame and credit,
I may goe off; I would not be a ſtrumpet:
O my dear Sir you know:

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: O truth, thou knoweſt too.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Nor have the world ſuſpect, I fell to miſchiefe.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Take you no care for that, here's that has don it;
A faire divorce, 'tis honeſt too.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: The devill,
Honeſt? to put her off.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Moſt honeſt Sir,
And in this point, moſt ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: The cauſe, the cauſe Sir?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: A juſt cauſe too.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: As any is in hell, Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: For barrenneſſe, ſhe never brought him children.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Why art not thou divorc'd? thou canſt not get 'em;
Thy neigbours, thy rank neighbours: O baſe jugling,
Is ſhe not young?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Woemen at more yeares Sir,
Have met that bleſſing▪ 'tis in heavens high power.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: You never can have any:

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Why quick Lawyer?
My Philoſophicall Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: The Rack has ſpoil'd her
The diſtentions of thoſe parts, hath ſtopt all fruitfulnes.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: O I could curſe.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And am I grown ſo miſerable,
That mine own pitty muſt make me wretched?
No cauſe againſt me, but my love and duty?
Farewell Sir▪ like obedience, thus I leave you,
My long farewell: I doe not grudge, I grieve Sir,
And if that be offenſive, I can dye,
And then you fairely free: good Lady love him;
You have a noble, and an honeſt Gentleman,
I ever found him ſo, the world has ſpoke him;
And let it be your part ſtill to deſerve him:
Love him no leſſe then I have done; and ſerve him,
And heaven ſhall bleſſe you; you ſhall bleſſe my aſhes;
I give you up the houſe; the name of wife,
Honour, and all reſpect I borrowed from him,
And to my grave I turn: one farewell more;
Nothing divide your Loves, not want of Children,
Which I ſhall pray againſt, and make you fruitfull;
Grow like two equall flames, riſe high and glorious;
And in your honor'd age, burn out together:
To all I know, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ronver.
sp.l: Be not ſo grie'vd Lady;
A nobler fortune.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Away thou paraſite.
Diſturbe not my ſad thoughts; I hate thy greatneſſe.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: I hate not you; I am glad ſhe's off theſe hinges,
Come, let's purſue. Exit Ronver. and Law.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: If I had breath to curſe thee;
Or could my great heart utter; farewell villaine,
Thy houſe, nor face agen. Exit Pand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let 'em all goe.
And now let us rejoyce; now freely take me,
And now embrace me Virolet; give the rites
Of a brave Husband to his love.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I'le take my leave too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How, take you leave too?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: The houſe is furniſh'd for you;
You are Miſtreſſe, may command.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Will you to bed Sir?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: As ſoone to hell, to any thing I hate moſt;
You muſt excuſe me, I have kept my word.
You are my wife, you now enjoy my fortune,
Which I have done to recompence your bounty:
But to yeeld up thoſe chaſte delights and pleaſures,
Which are not mine, but my firſt vowes.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You jeaſt.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: You will not find it ſo, to give you thoſe;
I have divorc'd, and loſt with Iuliana,
And all fires of that nature.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Are you a Husband;

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: To queſtion hers, and ſatisfie your flames,
That held an equall beauty, equall bounty.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Good heaven forgive; no, no, the ſtrict for|bearance,
Of all thoſe joyes, like a full ſacrifice,
I offer to the ſuffrings of my firſt love;
Honour, and wealth, attendance, ſtate, all duty,
Shall waite upon your will, to make you happy;
But my afflicted mind, you muſt give leave Lady;
My weary Trunk muſt wander.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Not enjoy me?
Goe from me too?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: For ever thus I leave you;
And how ſo e're I fare, live you ſtill happy. Exit Virol.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Since I am ſcorn'd, I'le hate thee, ſcorn thy gifts too;
Thou miſerable fool, thou fool to pitty;
And ſuch a rude, demoliſht thing, I'le leave thee,
In my revenge: for fooliſh love, farewell now,
And anger, and the ſpite of woman enter,
That all the world ſhall ſay, that read this ſtory,
My hate, and not my love, begot my glory.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: He that feares death, or tortures, let him leave me.
The ſtops that we have met with, Crown our Conqueſt:
Common attempts are fit for common men;
The rare, the rareſt ſpirits. Can we be daunted?
We that have ſmil'd at Sea at certain ruines,
Which men on ſhore; but hazarded would ſhake at
We that have liv'd free, in deſpite of fortune,
Laught at the out-ſtretch'd Arme of Tyranny,
As ſtill too ſhort to reach us, ſhall we faint now?
No my bravemates, I know your fiery temper,
And that you can, and dare, as much as men:
Calamity, that ſevers worldly friendſhips,
Could ne'r divide us, you are ſtill the ſame;
The conſtant followers of my baniſht fortunes;
The Inſtruments of my revenge; the hands
By which I work, and faſhion all my projects.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: And ſuch we will be ever.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: 'Slite Sir, Cramme me
Into a Canons mouth, and ſhoot me at
Proud Ferrands head; may onely he fall with me,
My life I rate at nothing.

sp.speaker: Boatſw.
sp.l: Could I but get,
Within my ſwords length of him; and if then
He ſcape me, may th'account of all his diinnes
Be added unto mine.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: 'Tis not to dye Sir,
But to dye unreveng'd, that ſtaggers me:
For were your ends ſerv'd, and our Country free,
We would fall willing ſacrifices.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: To riſe up,
Moſt glorious Martyrs.

sp.speaker: Boatſ.
sp.l: But the reaſon why
We weare theſe ſhapes?

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Onely to get acceſſe:
Like honeſt men, we never ſhall approach him,
Such are his feares, but thus attir'd like Switzers,
And faſhioning our language to our habits;
Bold, bloody, deſperate, we may be admitted
Among his guard. But if this faile, I'le try
A thouſand others, out doe Proteus
In various ſhapes, but I will reach his heart.
And ſeale my anger on't. Enter Ronero and the Guard.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: The Lord Ronero.

sp.speaker: Boatſ.
sp.l: Shall we begin with him?

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: He is not ripe yet,
Nor fit to fall: as you ſee me begin,
Withall care imitate.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: We are inſtructed.

sp.speaker: Boatſ.
sp.l: Would we were at it once.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Keepe a ſtrict watch,
And let the guards be doubled, this laſt night
The King had fearefull dreames.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: 'Tis a good Omen
To our attempts.

sp.speaker: Roner.
sp.l: What men are theſe? What ſeek you?

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Imployment.

sp.speaker: Roner.
sp.l: Of what nature?

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: We are Souldiers;
We have ſeen towns and Churches ſet on fire;
The Kennels running blood, coy virgins raviſh'd;
The Altars ranſack'd, and the holy reliques,
Yea, and the Saints themſelves, made lawfull ſpoyles,
Unto the Conquerors: but theſe good dayes are paſt,
And we made Beggars, by this Idle Peace,
For want of action. I am Sir no ſtranger
To the Government of this ſtate, I know the King
Needs men, that onely doe what he commands,
And ſearch no further: 'tis the profeſſion
Of all our Nation, to ſerve faitnfully,
Where th'are beſt payed: and if you entertaine us,
I doe not know the thing you can command,
Which we'le not put in act.

sp.speaker: Roner.
sp.l: A goodly Parſonage.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: And if you have an Enemy, or ſo
That you would have diſpatch'd.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: They are here, can fit you.

sp.speaker: Boatſ.
sp.l: Or if there be an Itch, though to a man,

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: You ſhall tye
Our conſciences in your purſe-ſtrings.

sp.speaker: Roner.
sp.l: Gentlemen,
I like your freedome: I am now in haſte,
But waite for my return. I like the Raſcals,
They may be uſefull.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: We'l attend you Sir:

sp.speaker: Roner.
sp.l: Doe; and be confident, of entertainment;
I hope ye will deſerve it. Exit Roner. and Guard.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: O, no doubt Sir:
Thus farre we are proſperous; we'l be his guard,
Till Tyranny and pride finde full reward: Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: My bleſſing? no; a Fathers heavy curſe,
Purſue, and overtake him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Gentle Sir.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: My name, and Family; end in my ſelf
Rather then live in him.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Deare Sir forbeare,
A fathers curſes, hit far off, and kill too.
And like a murthering-piece aymes not at one,
But all that ſtand within the dangerous level.
Some bullet may return upon your ſelfe too,
Though againſt nature, if you ſtill go on
In this unnaturall courſe.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Thou art not made
Of that ſame ſtuffe as other women are:
Thy injuries would teach patience to blaſpheme;
Yet ſtill thou art a Dove.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I know not malice, but like an innocent, ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: More miraculous!
He have a woman Chronicled, and for goodneſſe,
Which is the greateſt wonder. Let me ſee,
I have no ſonne to inherit after me;
Him I diſclaime.
What then? He make thy vertues my ſole heire;
Thy ſtory Ile have written, and in Gold to;
In proſe and verſe, and by the ableſt doers:
A word or two of a kind ſtep-father
He have put in, good Kings and Queens ſhal buy it.
And if the actions of ill great women,
And of the modern times too, are remembred,
That have undone their husbands, and their families,
What will our ſtory do? It ſhal be ſo,
And I wil ſtreight about it. Exit Pand.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Such as love
Goodneſſe for glory, have it for reward;
I love mine for it ſelfe: let innocence
Be written on my Tomb, though ne're ſo humble,
Tis all I am ambitious of. But I
Forget my vows.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: 'Fore me, you are not modeſt,
Nor is this Courtlike. Would you take it wel,
If ſhe ſhould rudely preſſe into your Clolſt,
When from your ſeveral Boxes you chooſe paint,
To make a this daies face with?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Pray know her pleaſure firſt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: To whom ſpeak you Boy?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Your Ladiſhips pardon. That proud Lady theife,
That ſtole away my Lord from your embraces,
(Wrinckes at two and twenty on her cheekes for't,
Or Mercury unallayed, make bliſters on it)
Would force a viſit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: And dare you deny her,
Or any elſe that I call mine? No more,
Attend her with all reverence and reſpect;
The want in you of manners, my Lord may
Conſtrue in me for malice. I wil teach you
How to eſteem and love the beauty he dotes on;
Prepare a banquet. Enter Martia and Boy.
Madam, thus my duty
Stoops to the favour you vouchſafe your ſervant,
In honouring her houſe.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Is this in ſcorn?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No by the life of Virolet: give me leave
To ſweare by him, as by a Saint I worſhip,
But am to know no further, my heart ſpeaks that
My ſervants have been rude, and this boy (doting
Upon my ſorrows) hath forgot his duty:
In which, that you may think I have no ſhare,
Sirra, upon your knees, deſire her pardon.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I dare not diſobey you.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Prethee riſe,
My anger never looks ſo low: I thank you.
And wil deſerve it, If we may be private,
I came to ſee and ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Be gone. Exit Boy.
Good Madam ſit.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I rob you of your place then.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You have deſerv'd a better, in my bed;
Make uſe of this too: Now your pleaſure Lady.
If in your breaard there be a worthy pitty,
That brings you for my comfort, you do nobly:
But if you come to triumph in your conqueſt,
Or tread on my calamities, 'twil wrong
Your other excellencies. Let it ſuffice,
That you alone enjoy the beſt of men,
And that I am forſaken.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: He the beſt?
The ſcum and ſhame of mankind.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Virolet, Lady?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Bleſt in him? I would my youth had choſen
Conſuming feavers, bed-rid age
For my companions, rather then a thing
To lay whoſe baſeneſſe open, would even poyſon
The tongue that ſpeaks it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Certainly from you
At no part he deſerves this; and I tell you,
Durſt I pretend but the leaſt title to him,
I ſhould not hear this.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: He's an impudent villaine,
Or a malicious wretch: to you ungratefull;
To me, beyond expreſſion barbarous.
I more then hate him; from you, he deſerves
A death moſt horrid: from me, to die for ever,
And know no end of torments. Would you have comfort?
Would you waſh off the ſtain that ſticks upon you,
In being refuſ'd? Would you redeem your fame,
Shipwrack'd in his baſe wrongs? if you deſire this,
It is not to be done with ſlaviſh ſuffering,
But by a Noble anger, making way
To a moſt brave revenge, we may call juſtice;
Our injuries are equal; joyn with me then,
And ſhare the honour.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I ſcarce underſtand you,
And know I ſhal be moſt unapt to learn
To hate the man I ſtil muſt love and honour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This fooliſh dotage in ſoft-hearted women,
Makes proud men inſolent: but take your way,
Ile run another courſe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: As you are noble,
Deliver his offence.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: He has denied
The rites due to a wife.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O me moſt happy,
How largely am I payd for all my ſufferings?
Moſt honeſt Virolet, thou juſt performer
Of all thy promiſes: I call to mind now,
When I was happy in thoſe joyes you ſpeak of,
In a chaſt bed, and warranted by Law too,
He oft would ſwear, that if he ſhould ſurvive me,
(Which then I knew he wiſht not) never woman
Should taſte of his imbraces; this one act
Makes me again his debtor.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: And was this
The cauſe my youth and beauty were contemn'd?
If I ſit down here! wel —;

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I date thy worſt,
Plot what thou canſt, my piety ſhal guard him
Againſt thy malice. Leave my houſe and quickly,
Thou wilt infect theſe innocent walls. By vertue
I wil inform him of thy bloody purpoſe,
And turn it on thine own accurſed head;
Believ't I wil. Exit Juliana.

sp.speaker: Mart
sp.l: But tis not in thy power
To hinder what I have decreed againſt him.
He ſet my ſelfe to ſale, and live a ſtrumpet;
Forget my birth, my father, and his honour,
Rather then want an inſtrument to help me Enter Ronvere.
In my revenge. The Captain of the guard;
Bleſt opportunity courts me.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Sad and troubled?
How brave her anger ſhews? how it ſets off
Her naturall beauty? under what happy ſtar
Was Virolet born, to be belov'd and ſought to,
By two incomparable women? Nobleſt Lady,
I have heard your wrongs and pity them: and if
The ſervice of my life could give me hope
To gain your favour, I ſhould be moſt proud
To be commanded.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Tis in you, my Lord,
To make me your glad ſervant.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Name the means.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tis not preferment, Jewels, Gold, or Courtſhip.
He that deſires to reap the harveſt of
My youth and beauty, muſt begin in blood,
And right my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: I apprehend you Madam,
And reſt aſſur'd tis done; I am provided
Of inſtruments to fit you: To the King,
Ile inſtantly preſent you; if I faile,
He ſhal make good your aymes: he's leſſe then man,
That to atchieve your favour, would not doe
Deeds, friends would fear to put their agents to. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Quid invitus facis, non eſt ſcelus. Tis an axiome,
Now whether willingly I have departed
With that I lov'd: with that, above her life
Lov'd me again, crownd me a happy husband,
Was full of children: her afflictions
That I begot, that when our age muſt periſh,
And all our painted frailties turn to aſhes,
Then ſhal they ſtand and propagate our honors.
Whether this done, and taking to protection
A new ſtange beauty, it was a uſeful one:
How to my luſt? if it be ſo, I am ſinful;
And guilty of that crime I would fling from me.
Was there not in it this fair courſe of vertue?
This pious courſe, to ſave my friends, my Countrey,
That even then had put on a mourning garment,
And wept the deſolation of her children?
Her nobleſt children? Did not ſhe thruſt me on,
And to my duty clapt the ſpur of honour?
Was there a way, without this woman, left me
To bring 'em off? the marrying of this woman?
If not, why am I ſtung thus? why tormented?
Or had there been a wild deſire joyn'd with it,
How eaſily, both theſe, and all their beauties
Might I have made mine own? why am I toucht thus,
Having perform'd the great redemption,
Both of my friends and family? fairly done it?
Without baſe and laſcivious ends O Heaven,
Why am I ſtill at war thus? why this a miſchiefe,
That honeſty and honour had propounded,
I, and abſolv'd my tender wil, and chid me,
Nay then unwillingly flung me on.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: He's here Madam;
This is the melancholy walk he lives in,
And chooſes ever to encreaſe his ſadneſſe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Stand by.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Tis ſhe: how I ſhake now and tremble?
The vertues of that mind are torments to me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sir, if my hated face ſhal ſtir your anger,
Or this forbidden path I tread in vex you;
My love, and faire obedience let behind me,
Your pardon asked, I ſhal return and bleſſe you.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Pray ſtay a little, I delight to ſee you;
May not we yet, though fortune have divided us,
Ana ſet an envious ſtop between our pleaſures,
Look thus one at another? ſigh and weep thus?
And read in one anothers eyes, the Legends,
And wonders of our old loves? be not fearful,
Though you be now a Saint, I may adore you:
May I not take this hand, and on it ſacrifice
The ſorrows of my heart? white ſeale of vertue.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My Lord, you wrong your wedlock.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Were ſhe here,
And with her all ſevere eyes to behold us,
We might do this; I might name Julian,
And to the reverence of that name, bow thus:
I might ſigh Juliana, ſhe was mine once;
But I too weak a guard for that great Treaſure—
And whilſt ſhe has a name, believe me Lady,
This broken heart ſhal never want a ſorroW.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Forget her ſir, your honour now commands you
You are anothers, keep thoſe griefes for her,
She richly can reward 'em. I would have ſpoken with you

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: What is your wil? for nothing you can aske,
So ful of goodneſſe are your words and meanings,
Muſt be denied: ſpeak boldly.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I thank you ſir. I come not
To beg, or flatter, onely to be believ'd,
That I deſire: for I ſhal tell a ſtory,
So far from ſeeming truth, yet a moſt true one;
So horrible in nature, and ſo horrid;
So beyond wickedneſſe, that when you heare it,
It muſt appeare the practice of another,
The caſt & malice of ſome one you have wrongd much;
And me, you may imagine me accus'd to,
Unleſſe you call to mind my daily ſufferings;
The infinite obedience I have born you,
That hates all name and nature of revenge.
My love, that nothing but my death can ſever,
Rather then hers I ſpeak of.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: To make a doubt of what you ſhall deliver,
After my full experience of your vertues,
Were to diſtruſt a providence; to think you can lie,
Or being wrong'd, ſeek after foule repairings,
To forge a Creed againſt my faith.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I muſt do ſo, for it concernes your life ſir;
And if that word may ſtir you, heare and proſper:
I ſhould be dumb elſe, were not you at ſtake here.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: What new friend have I found, that dares deliver
This loden Trunke from his afflictions?
What pitying hand, of all that feeles my miſeries,
Brings ſuch a benefit?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Be wiſe and manly,
And with your honour fall, when Heaven ſhall call you,
Not by a Helliſh miſchiefe.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Speak my bleſt one,
How weak and poor I am, now ſhe is from me?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Your wife.

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Your wife.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Be tender of her, I ſhal believe elſe —

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I muſt be true: your eare, ſir;
For tis ſo horrible, if the ayre catch it,
Into a thouſand plagues, a thouſand monſters,
It will diſperſe it ſelfe, and fright reſiſtance,

sp.speaker: Viro.
sp.l: She ſeeke my life with you? make you her agent?
Another love? O ſpeake but truth.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Be patient,
Deare as I love you, elſe I leave you wretched.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Forward, tis well, it ſhal be welcome to me;
I have liv'd too long, numbred too many daies,
Yet never found the benefit of living;
Now when I come to reap it with my ſervice,
And hunt for that my youth and honour aimes at,
The Sunne ſets on my fortune red and bloody,
And everlaſting night begins to cloſe me,
Tis time to die. Enter Martia and Ronvere.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: She comes her ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Believe Lady,
And on this Angel hand, your ſervant ſeales it,
You ſhal be Miſtris of your whole deſires,
And what ye ſhal command.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Ha mynion,
My precious dame, are you there? nay go forward,
Make your complaints, and poure out your faind pities,
Slave, like to him you ſerve: I am the ſame ſtill,
And what I purpoſe, let the world take witneſſe,
Shal be ſo finiſht, and to ſuch example,
Spite of your poore preventions; my deare Gentleman,
My honourable man, are you there too?
You and your hot deſire? Your mercy ſir,
I had forgot your greatneſſe.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Tis not wel Lady.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Lord, how I hate this fellow now; how deſpe|rately
My ſtomack ſtands againſt him, this baſe fellow,
This gelded foole!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Did you never heare of modeſty?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Yes, when I heard of you and ſo believ'd it,
Thou bloodleſſe, brainleſſe foole.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Thou deſpiſ'd foole,
Thou onely ſign of man, how I contemn thee!
Thou woven worthy in a piece of Arras,
Fit onely to enjoy a wall; thou beaſt
Beaten to uſe; Have I preſerv'd a beauty,
A youth, a love, to have my wiſhes blaſted?
My dotings, and the ioyes I came to offer,
Muſt they be loſt, and ſleighted by a dormouſe?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Uſe more reſpect; and woman, twill become you;
At leaſt, leſſe tongue.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: He uſe all violence,
Let him look for't.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Dare you ſtaine thoſe beauties,
Thoſe Heavenly ſtamps, that raiſe men up to wonder,
With harſh and crooked motions? are you ſhe
That overdid all ages, with your honour;
And in a little houre dare loſe this triumph?
Is not this man your husband?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: He's my halter;
Which (having ſued my pardon) I fling off thus,
And with him all I brought him, but my anger;
Which I wil nouriſh to the deſolation,
Not onely of his folly, but his friends,
And his whole name.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Tis wel, I have deſervd it.
And if I were a woman, I would raile too.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Nature nere promiſ'd thee a thing ſo Noble.
Take back your love, your vow, I give it freely;
I poorly ſcorn it; graze now where you pleaſe:
That that the dulneſſe of thy ſoule neglected,
Kings ſue for now. And mark me, Virolet;
Thou image of a man, obſerve my words well.
At ſucn a bloody rate Ile ſell this beauty,
This handſomneſſe thou ſcornſt, and flingſt away,
Thy proud ungrateful life ſhal ſhake at: take your houſe;
The petty things you left me give another;
And laſt, take home your trinket: fare you wel, ſir.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: You have ſpoke like your ſelfe;
Y'are a brave Lady. Exeunt Ronvere and Martia.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why do you ſmile, ſir?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: O my Juliana,
The happineſſe this womans ſcorn has given me,
Makes me a man again; proclaimes it ſelfe,
In ſuch a generall joy, through all my miſeries,
That now methinks —

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Looke to your ſelfe deere ſir,
And trifle not with danger, that attends you;
Be ioyfull when y'are free.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Did you not heare lier?
She gave me back my vow, my love, my freedom;
I am free, free as aire; and though to morrow
Her bloody wil meet with my life, and ſink it,
And in her execution teare me peecemeale:
Yet have I time once more to meet my wiſhes,
Once more to embrace my beſt, my nobleſt, trueſt,
And time that's warranted.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Good ſir, forbeare it:
Though I confeſſe, equall with your deſires
My wiſhes riſe, as covetous of your love,
And to as warm alarams ſpur my wil to:
Yet pardon me, the Seal oth'Church dividing us,
And hanging like a threatning flame between us;
We muſt not meet, I dare not.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: That poore disjoynting
That onely ſtrong neceſſity thruſt on you,
Not crime, nor ſtudied cauſe of mine: how ſweetly,
And nobly I wil bind again and cheriſh;
How I wil recompence one deare imbrace now,
One free affection! how I burn to meet it̄
Looke now upon me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I behold you willingly,
And willingly would yield, but for my credit.
The love you firſt had was preſerv'd with honour,
The laſt ſhal not cry whore; you ſhal not purchaſe
From me a pleaſure, that have equally
Lov'd your faire fame as you, at ſuch a rate:
Your honeſty and vertue muſt be banquerout,
If I had lov'd your luſt, and not your luſtre;
The glorious luſtre of your matchleſſe goodneſſe,
I would compel you now to be! — forgive me,
Forgive me ſir; how fondly ſtil I love you!
Yet Nobly too; make the way ſtraight before me,
And let but holy Hymen once more guide me,
Under the Ax, upon Rack again,
Even in the bed of all afflictions,
Where nothing ſings our Nuptials but dire ſorrows,
With all my youth and pleaſure Ile imbrace you,
Make tyranny and death ſtand ſtil affrighted,
And at our meeting foules amaze our miſchiefes;
Til when, high Heaven defend you, and peace guide you.
Be wiſe and manly, make your fate your own,
By being maſter of a providence,
That may controle it.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Stay a little with me,
My thoughts have chid themſelves: may I not kiſſe you?
Upon my truth I am honeſt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I believe ye;
But yet what that may raiſe in both our fancies,
What iſſues ſuch warm parents breed.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: I obey you,
And take my leave as from the Saint that keeps me.
I will be right again, and once more happy
In thy unimitable love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ile pray for ye,
And when you fall I have not long to follow. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Seſſe, Maſter, Boteſwaine, and Gunner, at one doore: Martia and Ronvere, at another.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Now we have got free credit with the Captaine.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Soft, ſoft, he's here again: Is not that Lady —
Or have I loſt mine eyes? a ſalt rhume ſeizes 'em;
But I ſhould know that face.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: Make him not madder,
Let him forget the woman; ſteere a lar boord.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: He wil not kill her.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: Any thing he meets;
He's like a Hornet now, he hums, and buzzes;
Nothing but blood and horror.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: I would ſave the Lady,
For ſuch another Lady.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: There's the point;
And you know there want women of her mettle.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Tis true, they bring ſuch children now,
Such demilances,
Their fathers ſocks wil make them Chriſtning clothes.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: No more, they view us.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: You ſhal play a while,
And ſun your ſelfe in this felicity,
You ſhal you glorious whore; I know you ſtill.
But I ſhal pick an houre when moſt ſecurely —
I ſay no more.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Do you ſee thoſe? thoſe are they
Shall act your will; come hither my good fellows:
You are now the Kings. Are they not goodly fellows?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: They have bone enough, if they have ſtout heart to it.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: Still the old wench.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Pray Captaine, let me aske you
What Noble Lady's that? tis a rude queſtion,
But I deſire to know.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: She is for the King, ſir;
Let that ſuffice for anſwer.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Is ſhe ſo ſir?
In good time may ſhe curſe it.
Muſt I breed hackneys for his grace?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: What wouldſt thou do
To merit ſuch a Ladies favour?

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: That can ſupply thy wants, and raiſe thy fortuns?

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Let her command, and ſee what I dare execute.
I keep my conſcience here; if any man
Oppoſe her wil, and ſhe would have him humbled,
Whole families between her and her wiſhes —

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: We have ſeen bleeding throats ſir, Cities ſackt,
And infants ſtuck upon their Pikes.

sp.speaker: Boteſ.
sp.l: Houſes a fire, and handſome mothers weeping.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Which we have heaped upon the pile like ſacrifices.
Churches and Altars, Prieſts and all devotions,
Tumbled together into one rude Chaos.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: We know no feare ſir, but want of imployment.

sp.speaker: Seſs.
sp.l: Nor other faith but what our purſes preach.
To gain our ends we can do any thing,
And turn our ſoules into a thouſand figures;
But when we come to do —

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: I like theſe fellowes.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Be ready and waite here within this houre
Ile ſhew you to the King, and he ſhall like ye:
And if you can deviſe ſome entertainment
To fill his mirth, ſuch as your Countrey uſes,
Preſent it, and Ile ſee it grac'd.
After this Comicke Scene we ſhall imploy you,
For one muſt die.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: What is he ſir? ſpeak boldly,
For we dare boldly do.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: This Ladies husband;
His name is Virolet.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: We ſhall diſpatch it. Exit Martia, Ronvere
O damned, damned thing: a baſe whore firſt,
And then a murtherer; Ile look to you.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: Can ſhe be grown ſo ſtrange?

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: She has an itch;
Ile ſcratch you my deare daughter, Ile ſo claw you;
Ile curry your hot hide; married and honour'd?
And turn thoſe holy bleſſings into brothels?
Your beauty into blood? Ile hunt your hotneſſe.
Ile hunt you like a traine.

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: We did all pity her.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Hang her, ſhe is not worth mans memory;
She's falſe and baſe, and let her fright all ſtories.
Wel, though thou beeſt mine enemy, Ile right thee,
And right thee Nobly.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: Faith ſir, ſince ſhe muſt goe,
Let's ſpare as few as may be.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: We'l take all,
And like a torrent ſweep the ſlaves before us.
You dare endure the worſt?

sp.speaker: Maſt.
sp.l: You know our hearts ſir,
And they ſhal bleed the laſt, erſt we ſtart from ye.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: We can but die, and ere we come to that,
We ſhal pick out ſome few examples for us.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Then wait the firſt occaſion, and like Curtius,
Ile leap the gulph before you, fearleſſe leap it:
Then follow me like men, and if our vertues
May boy our Countrey up, and ſet her ſhining
In her firſt ſtate; our fair revenges taken,
We have our Noble ends, or elſe our aſhes. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: As you are Noble, keep me from diſcovery,
And let me onely run a ſtrangers fortune;
For when the King ſhall find I am his daughter
He ever holds moſt ominous, and hates moſt:
With what eyes can he look, how entertain me,
But with his feares and cruelties?

sp.speaker: Aſc.
sp.l: I have found you,
Suſpect not. I am bound to what you like beſt,
What you intend. I dare not be ſo curious
To queſtion now; and what you are, lies hid here.
The King comes, make your fortune, I ſhall joy in't.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: All things are ready ſir to make you merry,
And ſuch a King you ſhall behold him now.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I long for't,
For I have need of mirth.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: The Lady ſir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Now as I am a King, a ſprightly beauty,
A goodly ſweet aſpect! my thanks Ronvere,
My beſt thanks; on your lips I ſeale your wiſhes,
Be what you can; imagine mine, and happy.
And now ſit downe and ſmile; come my Aſcanio;
And let this Monarch enter. Enter Seſſ. and Mr. Boriſw. Gunner, and Saylors.

sp.speaker: Rover.
sp.l: Theſe are the Switzers.
I told your grace of.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Goodly promiſing fellowes,
With faces to keep fooles in awe, I like 'em;
Goe guard the preſence well, and doe your duties,
To morrow I ſhall take a further view:

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: You ſhall Sir,
Or I ſhall looſe my will; how the whore's mounted?
How ſhe ſits thron'd? thou blaſing muddy meteor,
That frighteſt the underworld, with luſtfull flaſhes,
How I ſhall daſh thy flames? away, no word more:

div.stage: Ex. Seſſ. and his company. Floriſh Cor.
Enter Villio, Caſtruchio, Doctor, and a guard.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Now, here he comes in glory, be merry Maſters, meat conveyed away.
A Banquet too?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: O, he muſt ſit in State Sir!

sp.speaker: Aſca.
sp.l: How rarely he is uſher'd? can he thinke now
He is a King indeed?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Mark but his countenance.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Let me have pleaſures infinite, and to the height,
And women in abundance, many women, Enter Ladies.
I will diſport my grace,
Stand there and long for me.
What have ye brought me here? is this a Feaſt
Fit for a Prince? a mighty Prince? are theſe things,
Theſe preparations, ha?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: May it pleaſe your grace?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: It does not pleaſe my grace: where are the Marchpanes,
The Cuſtards double royall, and the ſubtleties?
Why, what weak things are you to ſerve a Prince thus?
Where be the delicates oth' earth and ayre?
The hidden ſecrets of the Sea? am I a Plow-man,
You pop me up with porridge? hang the Cooks.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O moſt Kingly:
What a majeſtique anger.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Give me ſome wine.

sp.speaker: Aſca.
sp.l: He cooles agen now.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Foole, where are my Players?
Let me have all in pomp; let 'em play ſome love matter,
To make the Ladies itch, I'le be with you anon Ladies;
You black eyes, I'le be with you
Give me ſome wine I ſay,
And let me have a Maſque of Cuckolds enter:
Of mine own Cuckolds,
And let 'em come in, peeping and rejoycing.
Juſt as I kiſſe their wives, and ſomewhat glorying.
Some wine I ſay, then for an excellent night-peece,
To ſhew my glory to my loves, and minions:
I will have ſome great Caſtle burnt.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Harke you brother:
If that be to pleaſe theſe Ladies, tenne to one
The fire firſt takes upon your own, look to that;
Then you may ſhew a night peece.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Where's this wine?
Why ſhall I choak? doe yee long all to be tortur'd?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Why, what is this? why Doctor,
Wine and water Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: 'Tis Soveraign for your heat, you muſt endure it.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Moſt excellent to coole your nigh-peece Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: You are of a high and cholericke complexion,
And you muſt have allayes.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Shall I have no ſheere wine then?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Not for a world: I tender your deare life Sir;
And he is no faithfull Subject—

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: No, by no meanes:
Of this you may drinke; and never hang, nor quarter,
Nor never whip the fool, this liquors mercifull.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I will ſit down ahd eat then: Kings when th'are hungry,
May eat I hope.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Yes, but they eat diſcreetly.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Come, taſte this diſh, and cut me liberally;
I like ſauce well.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Fie 'tis too hot Sir:
Too deeply ſeaſon'd with the ſpice, away with 't,
You muſt acquaint your ſtomack wih thoſe diets
Are temperately nouriſhing.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: But pray ſtay Doctor,
And let me have my meat agen.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: By no meanes:
I have a charge concerns my life.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: No meat neither;
Doe Kings never eat Doctor?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Very little Sir.
And that too very choice.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Your King never ſleeps Brother,
He muſt not ſleep, his cares ſtill keep him waking.
Now he that eats and drinkes much, is a dormouſe;
The third part of a wafer, is a weeks diet.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Appoint me ſomething then.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: This I feel good,
But it melts too ſuddainly; yet, how, that gone too! take away.
Ye are not mad! I charge you:

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: For your health Sir,
A little quickens nature, much depreſſes.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Eat nothing for my health? that's a new dyet;
Let me have ſomething, ſomething has ſome ſavour.
Why thou uncourteous Doctor, ſhall I hang thee?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: 'Tis better Sir, then I ſhould let you ſurfet;
My death were nothing.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: To looſe a King, were terrible.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Nay, then I'le carve my ſelf, I'le ſtay no ceremonies.
This is a Partridge Pye, I am ſure that's nouriſhing,
Or Galen is an Aſſe: 'tis rarely ſeaſon'd:
Ha Doctor have I hit right? a mark, a mark there?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: What ailes thy grace?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Retrive thoſe Partridges.
Or as I am a King—

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Pray Sir be patient,
They are flowen too farre.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Theſe are breath'd pyes an't pleaſe you,
And your hawkes are ſuch Buzzards.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: A King and have nothing.
Nor can have nothing!

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: What think you of pudding?
A pudding Royall?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: To be royally ſtarv'd,
Whip me this foole to death; he is a blockhead.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Let 'em think they whip me, as we think you a King:
'Twill be enough.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: As for you dainty Doctor, the Table taken away,
All gone, all ſnatch'd away, and I unſatsfied,
Without my wits being a King and hungry?
Suffer but this thy treaſon? I tell thee Doctor,
I tell it thee, in earneſt, and in anger,
I am damnably hungry, my very grace is hungry.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: A hungry grace is fitteſt to no meale Sir.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Some two houres hence, you ſhall ſee more: but ſtill Sir,
You muſt retaine a ſtrict and excellent dyet.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: It ſharpens you, and makes your wit ſo poynant,
Your very words will kill.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: A bit of Marmalade
No bigger then a Peaſe.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: And that well butter'd,
The ayre thrice purified, and three times ſpirited,
Becomes a King: your rare conſerve of nothing
Breeds no offence.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Am I turn'd King Camelion,
And keep my Court ith' ayr?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: They vex him cruelly.

sp.speaker: Aſca.
sp.l: In two dayes more they'l ſtarve him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Now the women, there's no food left but they.

sp.speaker: Aſca.
sp.l: They'l prove ſmall nouriſhment.
Yet h'as another ſtomack and a great one,
I ſee by his eye.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I'le have mine own power here;
Mine own Authority; I need no tutor.
Doctor this is no dyet.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: It may be Sir

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: Birlady, it may turne to a dry dyet;
And how thy grace, will ward that—

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Stand off Docttor;
And talke to thoſe that want faith,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Hot and mighty.

sp.speaker: Aſca.
sp.l: He will coole apace, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Faire, plump, and red,
A forehead high; an eye revives the dead;
A lip like ripeſt fruit, inviting ſtill.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: But O, the ruſhy well, below the hill,
Take heed of that, for though it never faile
Take heed I ſay, for thereby hangs a taile.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I'le get ye all with Childe.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.l: With one Childe Brother,
So many men in a Blew Coat.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Had I fed well.
And drank good ſtore of wine, ye had been bleſt all,
Bleſt all with double Births; come kiſſe me greedily,
And think no more upon your fooliſh Husbands,
They are tranſitory things: a Kings fame meets you,

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Vaniſh away. Ex. Women.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: How, they gone too? my guard there:
Take me this devill Doctor, and that foole there,
And ſow 'em in a ſack; bring back the women,
The lovely women, drown theſe rogues or hang 'em.

sp.speaker: Aſca.
sp.l: He is in earneſt Sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: In ſerious earneſt, Enter Seſſ. Maſter, Boatſw. Gunner and Saylors.
I miſt needs take him off.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Now, now be free.
Now liberty, now Country-men, ſhake from ye
The Tyrants yoake.
All Liberty, liberty, liberty.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Treaſon, treaſon, treaſon.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: We are betrayed, fly to the town, cry Treaſon,
And raiſe our faithfull friends; O my Aſcanio.

sp.speaker: ſca.
sp.l: Make haſte, we have way enough.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Treaſon, treaſon. Ex. Fer. Aſca. and guard.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Spare none, put all to th' ſword: a vengeance ſhake thee;
Art thou turn'd King againe?

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: I am a raſcall:
Spare me but this time, if ever I ſee King more,
Or once beleeve in King▪

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: The ports are ours.
The treaſure and the port, fight bravely Gentlemen;
Cry to the Town, cry liberty and honour;
Waken their perſecuted ſoules, cry loudly, One of crying Liberty and freedome.
We'l ſhare the wealth among ye.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Doe you heare Captaine?
If ever you heare me, name a King.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: You ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Or though I live under one, obey him.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: This rogue againe.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Away with him good Gunner.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Why look ye Sir? I'le put you to no charg;
I'le never eat.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: I'le take a courſe, you ſhall not.
Come, no more words. Enter Boatſw.

sp.speaker: Caſt.
sp.l: Say nothing when you kill me.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: He's taken to the Towers ſtrength;
Now ſtand ſure Gentlemen.
We have him in a pen, he cannot ſcape us,
The reſt oth'Caſtle's ours; liberty, liberty:
What is this City up?

sp.speaker: Boatſw.
sp.l: They are up and glorious,
And rouling like a ſtorm they come; their Tents
Ring nothing but liberty and freedome.
The women are in Arms too.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Let 'em come all.
Honour and liberty.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Honour and liberty. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This womans threats, her eyes, even red with fury
Which like prodigious meteors, foretold
Aſſur'd deſtruction, are ſtill before me.
Beſides I know ſuch natures unacquainted
With any meane, or in their love, or hatred,
And ſhe that dar'd all dangers to poſſeſſe him,
Will check at nothing, to revenge the loſſe
Of what ſhe held ſo deare, I firſt diſcover'd
Her bloody purpoſes, which ſhe made good,
And openly profeſs'd 'em; that in me
Was but a cold affection; charity
Commands ſo much to all; for Virolet
Me thinks I ſhould forget my Sexes weakneſſe,
Riſe up, and dare beyond a womans ſtrength;
Then doe, not counſell: he is too ſecure,
And in my judgement, 'twere a greater ſervice
To free him from a deadly Enemy,
Then to get him a friend. I undertooke too,
To croſſe her plots, oppos'd my piety,
Againſt her malice; and ſhall vertue ſuffer?
No Martia, wer't thou here equally armed,
I have a cauſe, ſpite of thy maſculine breeding,
That would aſſure the victory: my angell
Direct and help me. Enter Virolet, like Ronvere.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: The State in Combuſtion,
Part of the Cittadell forc'd, the treaſure ſeiz'd on;
The guards corrupted, arme themſelves againſt
Their late protected Maſter; Ferrant fled too,
And with ſmall ſtrength, into the Caſtles Tower,
The onely Aventine, that now is left him?
And yet the undertakers, nay, performers,
Of ſuch a brave and glorious enterprize,
Are yet unknown: they did proceed like men,
I like a childe; and had I never truſted
So deep a practiſe unto ſhallow fools,
Beſides my ſoules peace, in my Iuliana,
The honour of this action had been mine,
In which, accurs'd, I now can claime no ſhare.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ronvere! 'tis he, a thing, next to the devill
I moſt deteſt, and like him terrible;
Martia's right hand, the Inſtrument I feare too,
That is to put her bloody will into act.
Have I not will enough, and cauſe too mighty?
Weake womens fear, fly from me.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Sure this habit,
This likeneſſe to Ronvere which I have ſtudied,
Either admits me ſafe to my deſigne,
Which I too cowardly have halted after,
And ſuffer'd to be raviſh't from my glory;
Or ſincks me and my miſeries together;
Either concludes me happy.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: He ſtands muſing,
Some miſchiefe is now hatching:
In the full meditation, of his wickneſſe,
I'le ſink his curſed ſoule: guid my hand heaven,
And to my tender arm give ſtrength and fortun,
That I may doe a pious deed all ages
Shall bleſſe my name for; all remembrance Crown me.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: It ſhall be ſo.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It ſhall not, take that token,
And beare it the luſtfull Arms of Martia,
Tell her, for Ʋirolets deare ſake, I ſent it.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: O I am happy, let me ſee thee,
That I may bleſſe the hand that gave me liberty,
O courteous hand, nay, thou haſt done moſt nobly,
And heaven has guided thee, 'twas their great juſtice;
O bleſſed wound, that I could come to kiſſe thee!
How beautifull, and ſweet thou ſheweſt!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Sighe not,
Nor weep not Deare, ſhed not thoſe ſoveraign Balſoms
Into my blood; which muſt recover me;
Then I ſhall live again, to doe a miſchiefe,
Againſt the mightineſſe of love and vertue,
Some baſe unhallowed hand ſhall rob thy right off.
Help me, I faint: ſo.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: O unhappy wench!
How has my zeale abus'd me? you that guard vertue,
Were ye aſleep? or doe you laugh at innocence?
You ſuffer'd this miſtake? O my deare Virolet!
An everlaſting curſe follow that forme
I ſtrook thee in his name ever blaſted;
For his accurſed ſhadow has betrayed
The ſweetneſſe of all youth, the nobleneſſe,
The honour, and the valor; wither'd for ever
The beauty and the bravery of all mankind:
O my dull, devils eyes.

sp.speaker: Ʋir.
sp.l: I doe forgive you,
By this, and this I doe; I know you were cozend;
The ſhadow of Ronvere, I know you aym'd at,
And not at me; but 'twas moſt neceſſary,
I ſhould be ſtruk, ſome hand above directed you,
For Juliana could not ſhew her juſtice
Without depriving high heaven of his glory,
Or any ſubject fit for her, but Virolet;
Forgive me too, and take my laſt breath ſweet one,
This the new marriage of our ſoules together;
Thinke of me Iuliana, but not often,
For feare my faults ſhould burthen your affections,
Pray for me, for I faint.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: O ſtay a little,
A little little Sir.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Fye Iuliana.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Shall I outlive the vertue, I have murderd?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Hold, or thou hateſt my peace; give me the dag|ger;
On your obedience, and your love, deliver it.
If you doe thus, we ſhall not meet in heaven ſweet;
No guilty blood comes there; kill your intentions,
And then you conquer: there where I am going,
Would you not meet me Deare?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: And ſtill love me?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: And ſtill behold you.

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Live then till heaven cals you,
Then ripe and full of ſweetneſſe you riſe Sainted.
Then I that went before you to prepare,
Shall meet and welcome you, and daily court you
With Hymnes of holy Love— I goe out,
Give me your hand, farewell, in peace farewell,
Remember me, farewell. dyes.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Sleep you ſweet glaſſes,
An everlaſting ſlumber Crown thoſe Chriſtals,
All my delight adue, farewell, Deare Virolet,
Deare, Deare, moſt Deare; O I can weep no more,
My body now is fire, and all conſuming,
Here will I ſit, forget the world, and all things,
And onely waite what heaven ſhall turne me to,
For now me thinkes, I ſhould not live, She ſits down.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: O my ſweet daughter,
The worke is finiſht now, I promis'd thee:
Here are thy vertues ſhewed, here regiſter'd,
And here ſhall live for ever.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Blot it, burne it.
I have no vertue, hatefull I am as hell is.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Is not this Ʋirolet?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.l: Aske no more queſtions,
Miſtaking him, I kil'd him.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: O my Sonne,
Nature turnes to my heart again, my deare Sonne,
Sonne of my age, would'ſt thou goe out ſo quickly?
So poorly take thy leave, and never ſee me?
Was this a kind ſtroake daughter? could you love him?
Honour his Father, and ſo deadly ſtrike him?
O wither'd timeleſſe youth, are all thy promiſes,
Thy goodly growth of Honors come to this?
Doe I halt ſtill ith' world, and trouble nature,
When her maine pieces founder, and faile daily?
Boy he does weep certain: what bodies that lies by him?
How doe you Sir?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: O look there Lucio,
Thy Maſter, thy beſt Maſter.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Woe is me.
They have kill'd him, ſlaine him baſely, O my Maſter,

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Well daughter well; what heart you had to do this;
I know he did you wrong; but 'twas his fortune,
And not his fault, for my ſake that have lov'd you,
But I ſee now, you ſcorne me too.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: O Miſtriſſe?
Can you ſit there, and his cold body breathleſſe?
Baſely upon the earth?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Let her alone Boy,
She glories in his end.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: You ſhall not ſit here,
And ſuffer him you loved- ha; good Sir come hither,
Come hither quickly, heave her up; O heaven Sir,
O God, my heart, ſhe's cold; cold and ſtiffe too.
Siffe as a ſtake, ſhe's dead.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: She's gone, ne re bend her,
I know her heart, ſhe could not want his company:
Bleſſing goe with thy ſoule, ſweet Angels ſhadow it
O, that I were the third now, what a happineſſe?
But I muſt live, to ſee you layed in earth both,
Then build a Chapell to your memories,
Where all my wealth ſhall faſhion out your ſtoryes.
Then digge a little grave beſides, and all's done.
How ſweet ſhe looks, her eyes are open ſmiling,
I thought ſhe had been alive; you are my charge Sir,
And amongſt you, I'le ſee his goods diſtributed.
Take up the bodies, mourn in heart my friends,
You have loſt two Noble ſuccors; follow me,
And thou ſad Country, weepe this miſery. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Seſſ. Boitſwaine, Maſter, Gunner, Citizens, and Souldiers, as many as may be.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Keep the Ports ſtrongly mand, and let none enter,
But ſuch as are known Patriots.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Liberty, liberty.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: 'Tis a ſubſtantiall thing, and not a word
You men of Naples, which if once taken from us,
All other bleſſings leave us; 'tis a Jewell
Worth purchaſing, at the dear rate of life,
And ſo to be defended. O remember
What you have ſuffer'd, ſince you parted with it;
And if again you wiſh not to be ſlaves,
And properties to Ferrands pride and luſt,
Take noble courage, and make perfect what
Is happily begun.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.l: Our great preſerver,
You have infranchis'd us, from wretched bondage.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: And might be known, to whom we owe our freedome,
We to the death would follow him.

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.l: Make him King,
The Tyrant once remov'd.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: That's not my end.
'Twas not ambition that brought me hither,
With theſe my faithfull friends, nor hope of ſpoile;
For when we did poſſeſſe the Tyrants treaſure,
By force extorted from you, and employed
To load you with moſt miſerable thraldome,
We did not make it ours, but with it purchas'd
The help of theſe, to get you liberty,
That for the ſame price kept you in ſubjection.
Nor are we Switzers, worthy Country-men,
But Neapolitans; now eye me well:
And tho the reverend Emblems of mine age,
My Silver locks are ſhorne, my beard cut off,
Partaking yet of an adulterate Colour;
Tho 14. yeares you have not ſeen this face,
You may remember it, and call to mind,
There was a Duke of Seſſ, A much wrong'd Prince,
Wrong'd by this Tyrant Ferrand.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.l: Now I know him.

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: 'Tis he, long live the Duke of Seſſ.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: I thank you.
The injuries I receiv'd, I muſt confeſſe,
Made me forget the love I owed this Country,
For which I hope, I have given ſatisfaction,
In being the firſt that ſtir'd, to give it freedome;
And with your loves and furtherance, will call back,
Long baniſht peace, and plenty, to this people;

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: Lead where you pleaſe, we'l follow.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.l: Dare all dangers.

div.stage: Enter Pandulf, the Bodies of Ʋirolet, and Iuliana, upon a Hearſe.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: What ſolemne funeral's this?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: There reſt a while,
And if't be poſſible there can be added
Wings to your ſwift deſire of juſt revenge,
Hear, (if my teares will give way to my words)
In briefe a moſt ſad ſtory.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Speake, what are they?
I know thee well Pandulfe.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: My beſt Lord?
As farre as ſorrow will give leave, moſt welcome;
This Virolet was, and but a Sonne of mine,
I might ſay, the moſt hopefull of our Gentry;
And though unfortunate, never Ignoble:
But I'le ſpeake him no further. Look on this,
This face, that in a Savage would move pitty,
The wonder of her Sex; and having ſaid
'Tis Iuliana, Eloquence will want words
To ſet out her deſervings; this bleſt Lady
That did indure the Rack, to ſave her Husband,
That Husband, who, in being forc'd to leave her,
Indur'd a thouſand tortures; By what practiſe,
I know not, (bur 'twas ſure a cunning one)
Are made, the laſt I hope, but ſad examples
Of Ferrands Tyranny. Convey the bodies hence.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Expreſſe your ſorrow
In your revenge, not teares, my worthy Souldiers:
That fertile earth, that teem'd ſo many children,
To feed his cruelty, in her wounded wombe,
Can hardly now receive 'em.

sp.speaker: Boatſw.
sp.l: We are cold,
Cold walls ſhall not keep him from us.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: Were he cover'd with mountaines, and roome onely for a
Bullet to be ſent levell at him, I would ſpeed him.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Let's ſcale this petty Towre; at Sea we are Falcons,
And fly unto the maine top in a moment.
What then can ſtop us here?

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: We'l teare him peece-meale.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Or eat a paſſage to him.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Let diſcretion
Direct your anger; that's a victory,
Which is got with leaſt loſſe, let us make ours ſuch:
And therefore friends, while we hold parly here,
Raiſe your ſcalado, on the other ſide,
But enter'd weake, your ſuffrings. Ex. Saylors and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: 1 Cit.
sp.l: In our wrongs.
There was no meane.

sp.speaker: 2 Cit.
sp.l: Nor in our full revenge
Will we know any.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Be appeas'd good man,
No ſorrow can redeem them from deaths Priſon;
What his inevitable hand hath ſeiz'd on,
The world cannot recover. All the comfort
That I can give to you, is to ſee vengeance
Pour'd dreadfully upon the Authors head,
Of which their aſhes may be ſenſible,
That have falne by him. ſound a parly.

div.stage: Enter Ferrand, Martia, Aſcanio, and Ronvere, above.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: They appeare.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'Tis not that we eſteme rebellious Traytors
Worthy an anſwer to their proudeſt Sommons
That we vouchſafe our preſence; or to exchange
One ſyllable with 'em: but to let ſuch know,
Though Circled round with treaſon, all points bent
As to their Center at my heart, 'tis free,
Free from feare villaines, and in this weake Tower
Ferrand commands as abſolute, as when
He trod upon your necks, and as much ſcornes you.
And when the Sunne of Majeſty ſhall breake through
The clouds of your rebellion, every beame
Inſtead of comfortable heate, ſhall ſend
Conſuming plagues among you; and you call
That government which you term'd tyrannous
Hereafter, gentle.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Flatter not thy ſelfe
With theſe deluding hopes, thou cruell beaſt,
Thou art ith' toyle, and the glad Huntſmam prouder,
By whom thou art taken, of his prey, then if
(Like thee) he ſhould command, and ſpoile his Forreſt.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: To thy horror, Duke of Seſſe.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The Divel.

sp.speaker: Seſſ.
sp.l: Reſerv'd for thy damnation.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Why ſhakes my love?

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: O I am loſt for ever;
Mountains divide me from him; ſome kind hand
Prevent our fearfull meeting: Or lead me
To the ſteep rock, whoſe rugged brows are bent
Upon the ſwelling main; there let me hide me:
And as our bodies then ſhall be divided,
May our ſoules never meet.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Whence grows this, Sweeteſt?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There are a thouſand furies in his looks;
And in his deadly ſilence more loud horror,
Then when in Hell the tortur'd and tormentors
Contend whoſe ſhreeks are greater. Wretched me!
It is my father.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Yes, and I wil own her, Sir,
Till my revenge. It is my daughter, Ferrand;
My daughter, thou haſt whor'd.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I triumph in it:
To know ſhe's thine, affords me more true pleaſure,
Then the act gave me, When even at the height,
I crack'd her Virgin zone. Her ſhame dwell on thee,
And all thy family; may they never know
A female iſſue, but a whore, Aſcanio.
Ronvere, look cheerfully; be thou a man too,
And learn of me to die. That we might fall,
And in our ruines ſwallow up this Kingdom,
Nay the whol world, and make a ſecond Chaos.
And if from thence a new beginning riſe,
Be it recorded this did end with us;
And from our duſt hath embryon.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: I liv'd with you,
And wil die with you; your example makes me
Equally bold.

sp.speaker: Aſe
sp.l: And I reſolv'd to beare
What ere my fate appoints me.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: They are ours,
Now to the ſpoyle.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: Pity the Lady; to all elſe be deaft. Exeunt.
Within, Kill, kill, kill. Alarum, Flo. Trumpets.

div.stage: Enter Seſſe with Ferrands head, the Citizens, Maſter, Boteſwain, Gunner, Souldiers, bringing in Aſcanio and Martia.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Cruell beginnings meet with cruell ends;
And the beſt ſacrifice to Heaven for peace,
Is tyrants blood: and thoſe that ſtuck faſt to him,
Fleſh'd inſtruments in his commands to miſchiefe,
With him diſpatch'd.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: They are all cut off.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Tis well.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Thanks to the Duke of Seſſe.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Pay that to Heaven,
And for a generall joy, give generall thanks:
For bleſſings nere deſcend from Heaven, but when
A gratefull Sacrifice aſcends from men.
To your devotion; leave me; there's a Scene,
Which I would act alone; yet you may ſtay,
For wanting juſt ſpectators, twill be nothing.
The reſt forbeare me.

sp.speaker: Citizens.
sp.l: Liberty liberty, liberty.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I would I were as far beneath the Centre,
As now I ſtand above it; how I tremble!
Thrice happy they that dyed; I dying live
To ſtand the whirlwind of a fathers fury.
Now it moves toward me.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Thou, I want a name,
By which to ſtile thee: All articulate ſounds
That do expreſſe the miſchiefe of vile woman,
That are, or have been, or ſhall be, are weak
To ſpeak thee to the height. Witch, parricide,
For thou, in taking leave of modeſty,
Haſt kild thy father, and his honour loſt;
He's but a walking ſhadow, to torment thee.
To leave, and rob thy father; then ſet free
His foes, whoſe ſlavery he did prefer
Above all treaſure, was a ſtrong defeazance
To cut off, even the ſureſt bonds of mercy.
After all this, having given up thy ſelfe,
Like to a ſenſuall beaſt, a ſlave to luſt,
To play the whore, and then (high Heaven it racks me)
To finde out none to quench thy appetite,
But the moſt cruell King, whom next to Hell,
Thy father hated; and whoſe black imbraces
Thou ſhouldſt have fled from, as the whips of furies;
What canſt thou look for?

div.stage: Enter Pandulph, and bodies borne on the Herſe.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Death; and tis not in you
To hurt me further: my old reſolution,
Take now the place of feare; in this I liv'd,
In this Ile die, your daughter.

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: Look but here;
You had, I know, a guilty hand in this;
Repent it Lady.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Juliana dead?
And Virolet?

sp.speaker: Pand.
sp.l: by her unwilling hand.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.l: Fates you are equall. What can now fall on me,
That I wil ſhrink at? now unmov'd I dare
Look on your anger, and not bend a knee
To aske your pardon: let your rage run higher
Then billows raiſ'd up by a violent Tempeſt,
And be as that is, deafe to all intreaties:
They are dead, and I prepar'd; for in their fall
All my deſires are ſum'd up.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Impudent too?
Die in it wretch.

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: Stay ſir. Botſw. kils her.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: How dar'ſt thou villaine,
Snatch from my ſword the honour of my juſtice?

sp.speaker: Botſ.
sp.l: I never did you better ſervice ſir,
Yet have been ever faithfull. I confeſſe
That ſhe deſerv'd to die; but by whoſe hand?
Not by a fathers. Double all her guilt,
It could not make you innocent, had you done it.
In me tis murder, in you twere a crime
Heaven could not pardon. Witneſſe that I love you,
And in that love I did it.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: Thou art Noble,
I thank thee for't; the thought of her die with her.

sp.speaker: Aſcan.
sp.l: My turn is next: ſince ſhe could finde no mercy,
What am I to expect?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: With one voyce, ſir,
The Citizens ſalute you, with the ſtile
Of King of Naples.

sp.speaker: Seſ.
sp.l: I muſt be excus'd,
The burden is too heavy for my ſhoulder,
Beſtow it where tis due. Stand forth Aſcanio,
It does belong to you; live long and weare it,
And warn'd by the example of your Unkle,
Learn that you are to govern men, not beaſts:
And that it is a moſt improvident head,
That ſtrives to hurt the limbs that do ſupport it.
Give buriall to the dead; for me, and mine,
We wil again to Sea, and never know,
The place, which in my birth firſt gave me woe. Exeunt.
